reviewText: Serena is a darkly disturbing, emotionally wrenching, severely affecting short little gem. It takes less than an hour to play through. After having played two or three times already, it's a game that is short in duration but stays long in memory. I very much enjoyed playing this game and look forward to playing more games by each of the contributing designers.
voteText: 322 of 370 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It is important to tell upfront that this is not a game in the common sense of the word, there is no real gameplay here. This is an interactive story, so people not interested in that can walk along.

The whole game takes place in a cabin lost in the woods, where you unfold the plot by exploring objects and opening furniture. The main character is deftly voiced, his emotions are convincingly genuine. There is no jump scares, loud sounds, and so on, the fear comes from the well crafted story and presentation. The game world might be small, but each items hold lots of memories, and as the plot advances, you see them in completely different lights.

The length of the game is perfect (roughly 1h30) for what it aims to achieve, and the pace consistantly ramps up in tension. The writing is descriptive, metaphoric and subjective. The emotional side is highly nuanced, and despite the length, you will feel conflicted several times concerning the characters and the situation it presents.

In short: a free game with the quality content you expect from a commercial product. Be aware this is a condensed experience focused solely on storytelling.

reviewText:
This is a game for people who enjoy exploring.
You play a man, alone in his cabin. He does remember that he used to live there with his wife, but apart from that, his memories are curiosly elusive. As you examine his posessions, slowly his memories of his wife and the life they shared start to come back.
I very much enjoyed this little game.
The gameplay mechanics are very simple: you walk around the single room of the cabin and examine everything you see.
There are usually multiple things he will remember for every single item, and the thoughts they will trigger in him also change over time, as do the parts of his past he focuses on.
While the story is not particularly original, I really liked the main character's writing and felt it easy to connect to him.
The ending also left me thinking, in a good way.

reviewText:
First off, this is not, in the strictest sense of the word, a game. You literally just point & click to move the story along, there are no puzzles, and even the order in which you click on things makes only a marginal difference.

Second, this is a free install, and you can experience the whole thing in less than an hour. I'm giving it a positive recommendation as a promise that, if you happen to have an hour to kill, you can get something out of playing this, positive or negative. I really think it's that sort of thing where you just have to find it out for yourself and not spend your time reading lots of reviews first and go into it prejudiced.

Play it now, or put it on your list of things to do at some unspecified point in the future, your choice -- but stop reading the reviews. You can come back to them afterwards. If you read just one review, I hope it's this one. :-)

reviewText:
“It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.” ― Jane Austen, Pride and Prejudice

Serena is a short adventure game that packs a truck load of emotion, inviting you to investigate a painful mystery. When I was browsing through adventure games in Steam, the title took my attention, yet I never got the will to actually try the game while other games that I purchased before were in the waiting line. Now that I did, I'm positive that the story will haunt me for a while. I have to declare here and now: it is immensely difficult for one to write a review about this game without giving any kind of spoilers; but I will try my best.

We play the game as a middle aged man that shares a small cabin out in nowhere with his wife, Serena. He sits on the table and looks at a photo of him and his wife. He is unable to recognize his wife's face. What did her face look like? Her eye color? Was she smiling when they took the photo? Come to think of it, where actually is Serena? She is not there... and doesn't seem to be returning soon either. We take a stroll within the cabin, and try to find some clues about our wife's whereabouts. Every furniture, every memento, every stain makes a life. Every tiny detail scattered around presents us a fragment of our memory with her. What happened to her?

The game is your basic adventure. The only place you got is the small cabin itself, in which the developers managed to fit in a grand deal of story. The atmosphere is a marvelous success, accompanied by beautiful background music that reflects the mood in echoes. Everything around is dim, dark and dusty, as if the reality is old and static as our protagonist's perception. What is certainly remarkable for the gameplay is that; as our memory comes back and our perception change, associations that we have through objects do change also. That is key for the progress within this game. You click on an object for the millionth time - ok, I exaggerate, but at least 15 or so in given progress - , and you still discover something new about the story. The mood starts with faint, content reminiscence, growing to become heavy suspense and conflict; finally calling the trumpet to make room for pure wrath and agony.

You won't be using anything else besides your mouse to go through our protagonist's memory lane. And take note, the game IS really short. I've run through the game 2 times already, and it took me a bit more than an hour to complete it for the first time. Considering the length, the game doesn't have a save game option. You launch, you play, you complete and you exit. That's all there is. I believe the length of the game is one of the reasons that the game was startling. The last moment comes as a punch to your conscience.

Serena is a wonderful short story that you'll keep with yourself even long time after you finish the game. I've made some research and discovered that the developers' intention for the production bears a story of its own. The game is made to correct a wrong and outweigh the pleasant as an intention in gaming community. That's why the game is free to play. So, if you are an adventure player and enjoy high quality, yet disturbing narration, what are you waiting for?

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
So, this is a free title, so based on that fact, there really isn't a reason for you to not draw your own conclusions and form your own opinion.

For me, this was okay. It seemed pretty obvious to me how this would play out. The ending does leave a bit of mystery, and so you are left to decide what you think actually happened. It's really  not scary or shocking or anything, but it is definitely a dark tale.

The gameplay itself is super simplistic. Point and click left mouse, and you can use the space bar to highlight interactive items. Outside of that, it's all about finding the right sequences to unlock the next part of the story. Everything happens inside the cabin, so you aren't really going anywhere although you do move around the cabin examining stuff.

The voice acting was not all that great. Not sure why it was lauded on the store page, lol. Could have been much better.

The actual setting looked nice and the game was easy to grasp. The story itself...you can play through it in about a half hour.

My overall rating for this game would be 6 out of 10. It's not a waste of time, but it's not all that exceptional either. I feel they over hyped the collaborative effort of the various programmers/developers/writers. This game seemed more like the sort of thing you would create in a one or two day workshop (graphics notwithstanding). Still, it's free and very short, so why not give it a try and see for yourself. A lot of people seemed to have appreciated the artistic effort more than I did. You might be one of those. Check it out and see.

reviewText:
Well holy crap this is chilling.

Serena is a first-person perspective mystery adventure game with one of the darker stories and most shocking endings I've seen in some time. You're a dude in a small cabin who seems to have lost his memory. The story takes about an hour to complete, and throughout you'll be told the story of two lovers and try to find out why the guy is now alone. You'll explore the humble abode and hear the main character's thoughts on things as he tries to remember, as well as hear the echoing voice of Serena, his love who has seemingly disappeared with no reason. No real puzzles to speak of, just you exploring and being told a story that gets progressively more unsettling.

After you've clicked on everything, the atmosphere will slowly change. Through subtle lighting and musical cues you'll know that things aren't quite right. Keep going back and looking at the same items, find new ones, and discover the dark truth and even darker future of their story.

Starts off nice and serene (ha) but then Serena happens and... yeah, it's not exactly such a happy and sun-kissed place to be anymore. This game uses its cozy, cabin atmosphere and the storybook love story against you to great effect. It's not exactly a scary horror game, but it definitely features some horrific and scary components. The music is haunting, the atmopshere is increasingly forboding, and the sense of place is fantastic. Voice acting is awesome as well, with some very effective performances that go from loving to surly to veangeful.

If you like adventure games in the style of the developer's other games (like Scratches), or just games with a dark and morbid story that catches you off-guard near the end, definitely check this out. And it's free, so I'd say just go for it.

reviewText: It's hard for me to mention this title without also talking about the game Anna... so I'm not even going to try avoiding the comparisons. If anything, I'll probably end up using them as a stick to sort of beat this game with and show what it could have been. Both feature a man alone in a house in the woods forlornly trying to piece together the events of their past while their emotional and mental grip on the world gradually spirals out of control with the realisation of the true history that they have somehow forgotten. Both use a minimum of space for a maximum of focus on atmosphere and tension while also instilling the player with a sense of being extremely confined, to mirror the same trapped feeling the characters have, both in their current situation as well as their lives in general. Both also toy with many of the same themes and apparent approach to environmental design and other such aspects. But where they differ greatly is Anna is a fully fledged game complete with puzzles and an in-depth story that plays with the occult and supernatural forces, while Serena is more grounded in reality and has you walking around a single room for an hour examining things and listening to one man's flood of self-pity at the breakdown of a relationship.\n\nI'm all for games that aren't games"
date: but rather "experiences" that invite you to submerge yourself in a unique world and present you with an interesting story or something pretty to look at
recommended: and I think that's just as worthy an endeavour as any other form of interactive entertainment or art
hoursPlayed: but Serena fails badly on this count. The diminutive cabin is pretty well crafted and at least serves well in creating a bleak and withered feeling to reflect its emotional themes as it tries to draw in the player to inhabit the protagonist's state of mind. But the actual story and its characters never capitalise on that and are ultimately uninteresting and not especially likable. This is partly due to the male lead's voice acting which seems at times out of place and unconvincing (made even more jarring by the much more natural sense of the female voiceover)
voteText: but also by the writing that feels a little awkward or rushed through at times and just never really ingratiates the player to the subjects of its tale. It doesn't help either that the big story revelation is so annoyingly and artificially withheld until the right point in time when they want you to find it

reviewText:
Serena is more of a story than a game, but an experience such as this is a shame to let pass by. Because, in such a small place, a whole world unfolds.

The story takes place in a cabin far into the woods, and away from civilization. You, the narrator, struggles with your faint memories of your wife, Serena. You look around your home, trying to find mementos that may reveal truths, or even lies? Little by little, you start to remember what happened to both you, and your missing Serena. But still, some things remains unclear. In the very beginning, you two had a romantic relationship going on, but slowly, it all went in flames.

As you may already know. Serena is a dark story that can leave many questions inside your head. Certain things are clear, just not directly to your ear. The hope you had from the start has been turned into distress and defeat. You wandered alone in the fantasy of books and arts... now, who is the deceiver of hearts?

reviewText:
What is Serena?Serena is point and click game in the traditional sense. The game involves around the main character looking at objects and telling and remenbering the memories of the life with his wife Serena while he waits for her return to the cabin they call home.

Is this an horror game with spocky creatures or ghosts that jumpscare you? The answer is no, the game does have its dark moments but there is no monsters or anything like that.

Story Every object and furniture in the house has a story in their relationship which makes the story quite immersive. Some of them change in appearance according to what the main character has remenbered and is feeling.

Gameplay In this game you click multiple times in the various objects to get the various pieces of dialogue. Once you make a breakthough in the plot the ambience changes and the objects will then have new dialogue and some objects change their appearance along with the enviroment.

The game doesn't tell you but there is only two keyboard keys you can use: SPACE allows you to highlight all the clickable objects and ESC that makes you quit the game if you press it twice.
The game doesn't have a save feature but it can be forgiven since it is just an hour long.

Voice Acting The voice acting in this game is pretty good. I was expecting something really bad since it is a free indie game and all but I was suprised for its quality.

Conclusion This is a pretty good point and click game that delivers it's story quite well though the enviroment and the dialogue.

reviewText:
Serena is a short and atmospheric exploration game that plays like a simplistic point and click game without the usual gameplay elements such as inventories, puzzles or different locations and is set in a cabin in the woods, where you play as a man who seemingly lost his memory and now is trying to find clues about the whereabouts of his wife, Serena.

While the gameplay itself isn't anything special, it's the story that keeps the game going. It starts out as sort of a love story of a young couple but the further you progress and the more memories you regain, the clearer your mind gets and faces you with the sad truth of what your relationship with your beloved wife has become.

I don't want to spoil anything of the story, but it's an intense emotional rollercoaster ride throughout the ~1 hour of playtime and if you're looking for a relaxing game that tells both a sweet and sad story, make sure to check the game out.

It's free!

reviewText:
Product received for free

A short psychological horror game, Serena takes place in one location and there are only a few items to interact with: this is not a game where you collect scotchtape and a cat to make a fake moustache. Instead, Serena explores the thoughts of an unnamed protagonist as he is thinking about his life with his wife Serena.

The game is short but can still become frustrating, as it isn't immediately clear what causes the story to progress. Once you figure out the rules of the game though, which for me came after maybe half an hour of exploring, the story goes to its ending quickly.

As a free game with good production values and a really interesting story, Serena earns a recommendation without question.
But the main takeaway from this game I have is that  I would like to see a longer, fully realized game by the people behind this.

reviewText:
I am absolutely useless at horror games. Once, someone left me on my own in a dark room to play Dead Space on his phone with headphones on. I bailed before the first monster.

So I had reservations before downloading this until I realised 3 things: I was bored, I'm a broke student and the word 'Free'. What more did I need?

The key to this game's effectiveness lies in it's atmosphere, like all good games and indeed all good scary media forms. I wouldn't call the game 'scary' per se, more 'eerie'.
The premise is simple: a man waits for his wife Serena in their holiday cabin, while trying to piece their life together in his mind. The best part (no spoilers) is where there is a shift in mood: voice tone changes, eerie music creeps up on you slowly, the tone shifts and a tactile tension settles like the dust covering all this cabin's memories. The voice acting by both leads is very laudible for an independent, largely  fan-funded game.

The short version: Wonderfully atmospheric, disturbing, well-written game which will leave you uncomfortable in the best way.

There's nothing bad to say about this game. If you like good stories, then definitely worth to play through once, since it's a 30-40minutes long game, depending on how much you explore".

reviewText:
For the price point I can strongly suggest you waste an hour of your life playing this. That being said, it is full of artistic flaw as much as its strong points.

Pros: Great ambience and music. Wonderful design of the cabin to fit the *I'm assuming* desired feel. The female voice actor did her job well. The animations while few were well designed for the story. And oh god the plot twist...

Cons: The damn main voice actor reads his lines as if being teleprompted at 6am with not a damn in the world. Probably cuz he did it for free. He just didn't fit with the rest of the projects paticularly somber mood. His highlights were when he was angry and even that was bordering on dull. Aside from that, the repeating of dialouge after exhausting memories was a bit annoying, the cursor was bordering on non-intuitive, and...

Like I said, for free its worth the 1 hour acknowledgement of a decent piece of digital artwork. If they asked for money, I'd say pass it up. It tried hard, it really did; but it missed its mark somewhere and I'm guessing its because of its main actor and frustrating mouse interface.

reviewText:
Like many Steamers, I have a forever growing list of games cultivated for my minor addiction for purchasing video games. So in the perpetual sea of Steam deals and Humble Bundles" I am quick to ignore the freebies offered in my Steam library without a second glance.


The only reason I happened upon Serena was because I was flipping through my list looking for another game and noticed this indie adventure horror title. I dig horror especially when it's heavily reliant on the story. When I first ran Serena it reminded me of walking through the alleyways and rooms in Amnesia minus the scariness and evil things lurking around each corner. Created via the same game engine (Dagon) as the upcoming Asylum
date: Serena is a positive preview of what's to come this year when Asylum is released. As it's based in one cabin with minimal room to roam
recommended: it doesn't expect much from you and is a practically zero stress game. If you like watching horror films but dislike partaking in gory FPS games
hoursPlayed: you'll enjoy the ambiance in Serena. It has sinister context set in a mildly soothing atmosphere which is the best formula for an entertaining but laid back experience. You don't do anything but click random objects and read/listen to plenty of text. It's a fun change of pace for horror gamers and easy to sample for those less inclined towards the genre. Just sit back
voteText:
and enjoy the story. It's like those interactive flash games back in the day that just gave you a wicked storybook with sounds and moving pictures and that was it.


What's more
helpfulPercent:
the game has no control menu so once you start you should aim to finish as it hasn't got a save mode either. It doesn't require one as it isn't challenging to finish and relatively short to play. There are specific places you can click with your cursor to hear snippets of memories and clues to what has happened in that cabin which has a intense atmosphere of "something gravely wrong" from the get go.


After a few minutes wondering about
votesHelpful: clicking all you can
votesTotal: in turn collecting an abundance of information on the couple introduced in Serena

you may get stuck. If you do you always have the option of pressing SPACE BAR to toggle hot spots. That way you can scan any object you haven't checked out and move on with the story.

reviewText:
A game that makes you think and feel.

Back to the old school type of gaming where the graphics and the story takes the lead, No need to rush, no need to hunt achievements or run around like a headless chicken. Sit back, pour a glass of wine, relax and enter the world of Serena. This is an interactive short story that will captivate you, treat it like a book you get to both see and play.

A poetic, deeply disturbing story you help tell by guiding the character through his memories and emotions. What really happened? What are his true feelings? Are the happy times just an illusion or where they real? Perhaps the darker revelations and memories is just a bad dream, the paranoid delusions of a sick man?

With an amazing team and a fantastic narrator Serena really is an amazing gift to all of us, thank you.

reviewText: To everyone who has trouble progressing in this game or hating it because of the missing settings: Calm down! The game is more a story than a game. It took me about 25 minutes to beat it, and I listened to everything the character had to say. This is no ordinariy point and click adventure game. You'll never leave the cabin, because it's the only place this game takes place.  To progress in the story, you'll need to find certain spots in the cabin to trigger the main character's memory. The whole point of this game is to remember all about Serina. Check everything, even twice or more if neccessary. Revisit the photo on the table multiple times. If you found the correct trigger to regain some memories, the photo will change. You'll also notice a progress when the music changes or the character has a different emotional state and reacts differently to his environment.\n\nTo me, it was a very interesting experience. At first, I couldn't quite get in touch with the voice actor, but it soon wasn't a problem anymore. To learn so much about that woman Serina, although you're just in a small cabin, it makes it very special. I liked the sudden change of drama this game had, and sometimes, I was a little frightened. I try not to spoiler anything, but there is one part, it gaves me the shivers. Recommended to all folks who dig a good, well thought, even if small story with dramatic plot twists. It's free, and about 30 minutes fun. What reason is there NOT to play it?

reviewText:
It's been a bit of time since I've played Serena, but I find this game always tends to haunt me. Ooh, we're punning already...

There is one thing that Serena did well that I want to start off with. Serena tells an amazing story in a short period of time. You're in a cabin trying to recall what happened to your beloved and once your memories are becoming a little more clear, you're not so sure if it's madness or clarity. Things are not what they seem. This is a basic writing scenario. The point is to take these things, elaborate on them, and make them very strong. Serena excells at this and gives you a twist ending that leaves you staring at the screen and (at least for me) scrambling for more answers because I just couldn't believe what I saw.

It's a story that starts off simply enough and leaves you to click around for your answers. Things start off sweet and loving and shortly they become a more twisted vision of those love goggles" your character had on.

Serena is a simple point-and-click style game that is more of an interactive story than a heavy game. There are no heavy puzzles you need to solve other than progressing your mystery you're wrapped up in. You don't ever leave your cottage so there's no heavy exploration. This is not a walking sim. It's just you and your obsessive searching of your cottage and your grisly discoveries.

It really is a lovely game and for what it does
date: it does well. It is perfect in that respect. I love the attention to detail. There are slight changes made to your surroundings the further along you get. What was once beautiful suddenly becomes ugly and...well...disgusting.\n\nOf course
recommended: there is the caveat that it's just really a short story that's interactive. It doesn't do much else. Some people have mentioned their irritation with the narrator. Considering the short length of the game
hoursPlayed: I'd suggest if you can't stomach him
voteText: you'd just have to turn off your volume. Personally I found him fine. Maybe a little dull and uninspired at some moments
helpfulPercent: but nothing awful enough that I'd have to turn him off. Sure
votesHelpful: he talks a lot because you have to click on everything (no exaggeration) to progress the story
votesTotal:
but I really didn't get that irritated. In fact I kept clicking on the bookshelf because I wanted more Lovecraft references read to me.

This isn't a game for everyone. There's no action. None. Zero. This is your best example of "a free game to kill an hour or less". It's also something I'd probably suggest to people who are trying their hand at horror writing just to see an example of how to do slow reveals. This is a great learning piece of material as opposed to something that's perfect gaming-wise.

I loved this more as a reader than I did as a gamer. It's simple and it's just plain nice. Though admittedly
votesFunny: if someone is getting into horror games
commentsCount: this is probably the best thing you could offer them to get their feet wet before introducing them to more combat oriented games.\n\nSerena is like an ex I compare other games to. Shamelessly I admit this."

reviewText:
Grade: 85/90
Difficulty: Easy-to-moderate. Point and click is pretty easy, but the difficulty lies in finding some of the more obscure places to click which are not immediately obvious -- and going back to re-click them after discovering certain new things.
Pros: Very intriguing storyline. There is a lot of depth in the journey through the main character's psyche, which takes us through his entire relationship with Serena, helping us piece together why she isn't there and why he can't remember things. There are plot twists after you begin to feel comfortable with the knowledge you've gathered.
Cons: It can get frustrating when clicking items starts to give you repeated text, leaving you to blindly wonder where you have to seek your next clues and progressive text to continue the game. Determination is needed, and a highly developed sense of curiosity to make you determined to find out what happened. (Tip: There is no 'inventory' in the game, so when you pick up the one object, do not try to hit escape to find a menu -- that will exit the game and you have to start over. There is a correct place to put the object, you just have to find it.) The good news is that you only need an hour's worth of effort, because that's how long it takes to play the game in its entirety.
Replayable: No. Once you go through the game, there's really no point in replaying it unless you're showing a friend. It's very straight-forward in telling a story about Serena and her husband.

reviewText: They say that too many cooks can spoil the soup but in this case, an all star cast came together to create a haunting little game that will put you on an emotional roller coaster for one hour. All the action" takes place in a small one room cabin with you exploring knick knacks around the cabin and remembering your life there. As you remember more

recommended: you will be left with some very mixed emotions.\n\nIt is not everyday that gems like this show up for free. Don't miss the opportunity to be surprised by Serena."

reviewText:
Oh man.
I loved this. So. Much. It may be a point and click (and I, myself, am not a big fan of point and clicks), but holy hell. Even if you don't enjoy point and clicks, you'll love this, either way.
You play as a man, exploring his house for memories. He has no idea what has happened, nor have you. The story begins as a beautiful love story, a man searching for the truth in what has happened with his relationship with his wife, Serena. But as the story progresses, you begin to realize something mortifying.
10/10. Creepy. Very dark. Would play again.

reviewText:
Before you decide not to like this game, please consider that this is a simple point-and-click AND free-to-play game.

Serena makes point-and-click game as literal as it can get. It is all you do, point-and-click. But the game play isn't the main part of the game, the story is what pulls the game together. There is a lot to think about after you get a hold of what the story is trying to tell, it grinds more into you especially if you are/had been in a relationship. I would not say is this a horror game, but it does rub the creepiness into your skin.

I will say I will not recommend this to everyone. But if you like creepy small stories that slowly roots into your head, you should give Serena a shot.

reviewText:
I didn't read too much about this game so I wasn't entirely sure what to expect from it aside from it was supposed to be creepy. It really delivered on that front, through the entire game I had a sense of uneasiness. While I was playing I was sure I had the story figured out until a dramatic twist at the end happened.


+ A very creepy atmosphere
+ A fascinating, thought provoking story
+ Good twist ending
+ Every object you click has multiple dialogue options throughout the game
+ Free

- Sometimes I was totally unsure of what to do next (I might just be horrible at point and click though and I'll admit I had to find a walkthrough)
- Horrible voice-acting, really a pain to listen to and stopped me from feeling completely immersed in the story
- Doesn’t tell you what the controls are, escape automatically quits the game and it doesn’t save your progress, space tells you what can be clicked on


All in all I think you should definitely give this game a try if you are a fan of creepy story driven games.

reviewText:
This simple short game is a great demo of what Senscape could do with a larger title. Their previous game, Scratches, used a similar style but was all subtitled with no voice acting and could get a little clunky with transitions (So much so that it was constantly crashing). It's nice to see a game from Senscape getting voice acting and moving much smoother. The story is very fleshed out and empathetic with tons of dialogue to explain what's going on. Small elements change throughout the game to add to emotional journey the main character is going on. Be sure to play a few times to make sure you don't miss all the little details. The only downside was the end; it wrapped up to quickly. The player still has time to understand what is going on, but by the time you know the end is coming, it's over in 30 seconds. Something just seemed missing. Overall, It's definitely one of those psychological games that you will be pondering after it's over. And that's part of its charm.

Is it scary?
About a 5 or 6 on the scare meter. And don't worry there's only one surprise scare, the rest is suspense.

reviewText:
So in case you're wondering if this thing that suddenly jumped in to everyone's library is worth spending time on, here's my little review.

Do you have a little over an hour of your life to spare? If you do, I would recommend you putting aside that time for this short adventure. There is no save feature that I am aware of so you should probably make sure you have that hour when you won't be interrupted.
This game have focus on story telling and atmosphere, the graphics are what you'd expect from a free game and the voice acting can sound a little computerish at first but you'll get used to it. Everything is done by mouse, the only non mouse actions I've found are spacebar to find hot spots and escape to well...escape or exit game if you're looking for a better word.
The story is well written, intriguing and has plot twists. The twists are fairly obvious but they are still well written and goes hand in hand with the atmosphere. As you progress the story the lightning and sound effects does a good job of changing the mood, creating a creepy and gloomy atmosphere, and no - there are no jump scares.
It's a rather depressing themed game though, but if you're like me you love that stuff ;)

So if you have around an hour to spare, try it!

reviewText: Serena is a wonderful little one room adventure game. The art is emotive, evocative and atmospheric - you're a man who cannot recall his wife, or her face, as you start in an old, dusty cabin. I really enjoyed this - it's a short game, and a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.

reviewText: Wow. date: I had only corrected guessed one of a couple of shocking revelations.\n\nThis game is free

reviewText: If you are looking for a fast paced action game, keep looking. But if you want to be taken on a wild emotional rollercoster ride, strap yourself in and play this game right now! Well, maybe wait till night time. This game is amazing. The story is fantastic, Never before have i felt so many emotions in such a short period of time. It is blissfully serene one moment, and then the next thing you know your stomach is in your mouth. This game is very uncomfortable, yet paradoxically oddly comforting at the same time. I would recomend that you play this game alone, in the dark, with headphones on.\nGraphics are okay, they are not bad at all but not amazing. There are no options that i could find, this game is more of an experience than a video game though. Voice acting was okay, again not bad, but not fantastic by any means. Seeing as this game is free, i see no reason why you shouldn't try it at least. Yes it is a little bit boring and unclear at first, but just sit down and play it, you will not regret it. To anyone who gets stuck, all i can say is click on every item throughout the cabin, then do it again. Each time the story is furthered, also, click the item a few times to hear all of the dialauge. Anyways, DOWNLOAD THIS GAME RIGHT NOW AND PLAY IT!\n

reviewText:
***possible light spoilers***

An interesting ambience-style game similar in gameplay mechanics to games like Dear Esther. While the game only takes place in one main area, there is plenty to look at over time. One interesting point in the gameplay is that descriptions of items around the area change as you examine more things and uncover the story. The graphics are nice, as well.
One main con of the game revolves around the length. It is not, by any means, a long game. It took me less than an hour to play through it, and that included time taken commentating. It is a very intersting story, and it may have benefitted from being at least a little bit longer. It is also quite possible that being longer would only hurt the story. It's hard to tell.
The voice acting in this game is nice. It's not fantastic, but the main character's audio quality is pretty good. All in all, the voices certainly aren't unenjoyable.
In simple terms, Serena was a good game. It might seem boring or uneventful to some people, but to anyone that loves a good ambience-style game, this is certainly a game to pick up. Besides, it's free!

Feel free to check out my playthrough of this game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R84kazK_nRc

reviewText: Being a free game, I wasn't expecting much out of this, but I was pleasantly surprised at its quality. The voice acting is well done, and the ambience and design of the cabin gives the game a good sense of immersion. This game is in a similar vein as Gone Home, and Esther in that its more about the mood, setting, and story than it is about gameplay. There are no puzzles to solve, or complex mechanics to learn. You simply explore and interact with just about any object you can find to slowly uncover the cabins secrets.  The story dark, sweet, nostalgic, and increasingly creepy. It requires a fairly small investment of time, and is certainly worth playing through. Just a word of warning though, there doesn't appear to be a save function, so be sure to set aside at least 30-50 minutes to play it in one sitting. However, it can still be worth replaying as the dialogue changes, and you can get a fuller picture of the story. Definitely recommended.

reviewText: Good game but I have a few complaints. I felt that the writers tried too hard to sound deep and mysterious, there were too many metaphors in the letters (made me cringe) and it would have been better to simplify them just a little bit. Trying to sound deep in an adventure game isn't a bad idea just don't overdo it. Also, having to click around the room so much to progress the games story was a bit tedious in my opinion.  I will say the game had me beat at what really happened to the characters, at first I thought I knew what happened but then the game had a twist and proved me wrong so bravo to the developers.\nI do reccommend this to anyone looking for a short adventure game to play, the music and atmosphere is very nice and as the story goes on it gets darker and spooky.

reviewText:
For a free game, you get more than you bargained for. The game has a chilling atmosphere and a fascinating story.

The game features some very nice sound tracks and visuals. Each interactable object has various sound dialogues that have quite some depth to them. As you progress through the game, the story takes on an interesting turn and makes you a little emotional.

A full playthrough will take about an hour and is definatley worth it.

The one flaw that I can pick out is that the voice acting is a little dry, the actors could have put more emotion into it. But hey, it's free so I wasn't expecting Sir Ian McKellen to be featured.

reviewText: Serena is a lovely experience, if not a 'game' in the traditional sense. It's simple and haunting with a great atmosphere and story. You're confined to a one-room cabin where you examine a wide variety of things in the room and use the protagonist's musings to piece together the story. It uses sound very well to set the tone. The music is melancholy and tense, but when the music stops you can feel the uneasiness growing. The twist at the end was interesting and well-excecuted and leaves space for different interpretations about the details of what happened. Overall, the game is free, downloads in less than 10 minutes, takes an hour to play through, and is fully worth it. A great little story for a pensive afternoon.

reviewText:
***possible light spoilers***

An interesting ambience-style game similar in gameplay mechanics to games like Dear Esther. While the game only takes place in one main area, there is plenty to look at over time. One interesting point in the gameplay is that descriptions of items around the area change as you examine more things and uncover the story. The graphics are nice, as well.
One main con of the game revolves around the length. It is not, by any means, a long game. It took me less than an hour to play through it, and that included time taken commentating. It is a very intersting story, and it may have benefitted from being at least a little bit longer. It is also quite possible that being longer would only hurt the story. It's hard to tell.
The voice acting in this game is nice. It's not fantastic, but the main character's audio quality is pretty good. All in all, the voices certainly aren't unenjoyable.
In simple terms, Serena was a good game. It might seem boring or uneventful to some people, but to anyone that loves a good ambience-style game, this is certainly a game to pick up. Besides, it's free!

Feel free to check out my playthrough of this game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R84kazK_nRc

reviewText: I really, REALLY liked it. The atmosphere and soundtrack were top-notch and the story, at first, seemed really cliche, but towards the end got really cool, pulling out a completely unexpected ending that, get this, actually makes sense! It's easy to tell the makers of this game wanted to do something completely fresh and original and they succeeded brilliantly. It, at first, gives off a nostalgic, gentle feel that quickly turns to uneasiness and discomfort, then to a dark tenseness that envelops the setting. The color scheme remains the same throughout, but as atmosphere builds and soundtracks darken, everything looks more oppressive, dark, and tense. Very well done. This is one of the few games that really touches me emotionally: seeing something beautiful and ideal wither and die before your eyes is one of the hardest things to see for me and people who find that emotionally depressing or at least touching will very much appreciate this. Another thing I noticed: items you look at in the beginning take on a completely different meaning in the end, which is something I really enjoyed. Very very very good. Recommended completely to anyone who appreciates a good story, a good atmosphere, or a hella good soundtrack, even if it isn't the longest thing in the world...

reviewText:
Serena is such an immersive experience, the result of the efforts of producers who delivered a product that let the player be involved in the dark atmosphere of the cabin.

Being a point and click adventure, the focus is solely on the plot, on the exploration and the various twists you will be expecting, enhancing your feelings, making you build and destroy expectations and questions as you progress: the moment  you're sure of what happened in the cabin, it's when all your securities are smashed to the ground.

Serena leaves you a sour taste in your mouth after finishing it, this is what makes a game somethign more than a pixel adventure.

Just hit the Play Now button already. It takes few minutes to download it, and the game, as every unique things in life, won't last long.

You won't regret it!

reviewText: This is a great short story game.  Since it's free you owe it to yourself to play though this at least once.  The game tells the story of a man who has forgotten a few things about his life.  Throughout the one room you play in are clues to all the things you've forgotten.  It's a great story of love, loss, and emotions and will keep you guessing till the end.  Those of you who have ever experienced a long term marriage or relationship will likely feel quite a bit sympathy for the character as his story hits home the emotional roads that many relationships travel even though the ending is...well.... I don't want to give away too much.  It's a story that will likely stick with you for some time after you complete the game.\n\nIf you'd like a nice ride that last about 30 to 45 minutes give this one a go. reviewText: Serena is a first person point-and-click adventure. I wouldn't say it falls into the category horror, though it does have some creepy moments. Regarding whether the game has jumpscares or not:  No the game does not contain jumpscares . The story starts with you being in an old abandoned cabin and the only thing you remember is that you're waiting for your wife, but for some strange reason you can't remember where your wife is, no, you can't even remember her face. By walking through the room and searching for clues you try to piece together your shattered memory and uncover the truth behind this mystery.\nThe game is fairly short, you probably won't take longer than 1 hour to finish it. The story is really good and even better when you consider that it is a free to play game. The game is really atmospheric, entertaining and probably one of the best games you can get on steam for free.

reviewText:
Pewh...

... Serena... is not a game as defined by others you mostly play I guess. No options, no tutorial, no freaking plan what to do. You just start playing and....

... it´s rather an interactive experience

(SPOILER START)

you can get about a man developing his emotions and memories blurred by surpressed feelings  and unveiled by perception of sentiment. Madness comes to his mind, so did it come to mine, getting confused about how to understand his suffering and his side of view he has about Serena without knowing whether when it´s real and when it is blearily by his own impressions.

A great short story I would love to experience once more without my knowledge I gained about it already to get this terrifying and exciting feel again of how his thoughts change suddenly from pleasant to angry and destructive and even suicidal.

(SPOILER END)

Superb atmosphere, neat graphics and sound effects.

It´s a point-and -click you have to think for and about. I recommend it without hesitating.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: Interesting but not entirely compelling"
Personal Rating: 5/10
Genre: Point and Click Adventure/Psychological horror

In Greek mythology and the Homerian epics
date: madness is similarly thought of as a punishment from God
recommended: or the gods. Thus Hera punishes Hercules by ‘sending madness upon him’
hoursPlayed: and Agamemnon confides to Achilles that ‘Zeus robbed me of my wits’. Thanks to the Greek physician Hippocrates (460-377 BC)
voteText:
madness first became an object of scientific speculation.

So Serena (a short point and click adventure set in a single setting - a lonely wooded cabin) opens with a man waiting for the arrival of his wife. As we point and click on various items strewn about the incredibly run-down cabin (a not-so-subtle metaphor used to display the clarity of the mind of its main protagonist) cracks in the veneer begin to surface. Without going into too much detail its suffice to say gamers should expect to see exactly where this story is headed within the first five minutes of playing (the game roughly lasts about 40 min before concluding).

Whilst it's an interesting experiment that comes along with some pedigree - Josh Mandel of Space Quest fame handles the narration of the main character. My mine gripe is that he is probably not the person who should have handled these duties. He comes across as stilted when the script calls for emotional variation and I didn't buy it for one second. The woman who handles the wife's duties comes across as robotic in her line delivery even when called upon to display hysteria and it feels like both are reading from a script as the voice-overs just don't flow naturally. Yes -  I realize this is a free little title that probably didn't have the budget to hire professional actors - but having professional voice actors on-board would most certainly have been more beneficial.

I was also not mad about the main character voicing his thoughts about every single little thing I clicked on. Yes we may be dealing with a descent that's crux is akin to an emotional ship-wreck but having studied basic psychology at Uni before switching
helpfulPercent: I get that we are merely an observer inside another man's fractured mind but instead of drawing me in to the complexity of a mind unraveling I was left distanced and more and more annoyed as the tale progressed.\n\nShort and bleak this tale of love
votesHelpful: loss and misery is thankfully over quickly. I would hardly call it a "love-letter to the adventure gaming clique" as there are far better examples out there but as a mild diversion you may end up enjoying it more than I did since I can't say I was overly impressed."

reviewText:
Serena is a wonderful game that is artistic within its own right.

The game is entirely played within the cabin, and the game is played by interacting with objects within the cabin itself via point and click. The point of the game is the story itself, so interacting with each object gives you parts of the story (make sure that you interact with each object multiple times, though!). As the story progresses, you are able to re-interact with objects to obtain more of the wonderful story. You're able to interact with each object through 3-4 phases, each one giving you completely different dialogue for each object. The end of the story was both expected and unexpected at the same time (more-so when you get further into the game).

The voice acting itself was alright. The sad emotions seemed lacking (which is important within a plot like this), but everything else was pretty solid. The music was good when it was there, and the silence also empowered the general eerie feel of the game.

The biggest thing with this game is that it makes you feel so mixed towards the character by the end. You spend so much time sympathizing with this character, feeling confused for him, understanding his rage, but then you become infuriated with him beyond belief. It's an emotional roller coaster in the simplest of forms, and it keeps you thinking for a while after you finish it.

For a free game, this is really solid. I'd pay a few bucks for it, honestly.

reviewText:
Every once in a while, you need to take a break from the crazy fast paced games that lack any plot. Serena is a great opportunity for that escape. A very beautifully created point and click adventure story featuring a very dirty and gritty but appropriate environment. The plot follows the main character trying to regain some of his memories about his lost wife. The game does a great job at carrying the player through a gambit of emotions as well as helping to progress the story at an increasing accelerated rate.

The game was created using a brand new adventure engine called Dagon developed by the Argentinian studio Senscape. Senscape was founded by the writer and creator of Serena, Agustín Cordes who also created the hit adventure game Scratches.

Overall, if you enjoy story driven adventure games, this game is well worth the time. It was very short but considering the story, the length was perfect. This was just like sitting down to read to a great short story.

reviewText:
This comment is neutral.
The story is really simple: a man who doesn't remember anything about his wife Serena and he lives all alone in the house that they lived together in the past. All the game is inside this little house where pointing and clicking every single object inside the house you are able to rebuild all the story between the protagonist and Serena (and of course i will not reveal the final).
As a horror game it was in my opinion little bit aseptic: you can see the circle of the feelings of the protagonist (love-anger-disperation-depression) but i think are not really good connected to each other and as a player i wasn't able to feel the connections between them inside my mind. The only moment where i can found a connection is only when you are pointing and clicking some objects (with a particular order) without trasport the player FOR REAL into the deeps of the protagonist's mind.
About the graphic and the music nothing to say: i think they were good.
Graphic design is dark but simple and related with the atmosphere of the house. The same thing is for the music: easy going and good with the atmosphere of the game. But nothing to be surprised or something that said to you oh wow! This is great! Make me feels distressed as the protagonist!".
The gameplay as a point-and-click is really simple

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
In Serena, you won't find action or story-based choices. You'll find the narration of a story you can't change, but told in a very interesting way. The game is really worth the time you will put in it, which won't be too much over 1 hour. It might seem short, but for a free game, and for a story, it is enough. The end comes at the right time in my opinion, closing the story in a way i did not expect.
The graphics are not new gen great, obviously, but still very good; trust me, you have seen much worse in indie horror games. The textures settle the mood the story is aiming for, and some aspects of it are very detailed.
Overall, I would recommend it to anyone that likes a good story, and enjoys a good twist. Don't hesitate if you're tempted !
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: There is really no way to describe this. Serena is an overall great story, psychologically thrilling.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's been a long time since a game has stunned me in ways I thought was impossible...

And then, there's Serena.

The artstyle is fantastic. Although it looks gloomy and gritty, it sets the mood just right and puts attention to detail when needed, you will never miss an item or special event. Although it's nothing fancy, it helps set the mood for this game and it does a bloody good job too.

The gameplay is simple. All you do is click. It may seem a bit too simple but that's the genius part of it. It's so simple that you don't need to worry about controls while playing, which is a brilliant decision.

And finally, the story. Oh. My. ♥♥♥♥ing. God. Even though the story is simple, you can't tell what's going to happen next. I was astounded by the progression of the story and how my character was developing with every move I made. As the plot thickens, you will go on an emotional rollercoaster.

Do I recommend this game? I can't remember...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This game creeped me out. The feeling started out subtle and it grew as the story unfolded. If you like disturbing, it's interesting and doesn't take long to play.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is short, it takes an hour or so to play.
However, what it lacks in a need for time dedication it makes up for in terms of quality. This is a 5/5 game.
It draws out the lives of 2 characters from what I saw to be 3 or 4 different perspectives. It is a left click game, and pressing escape will quit the game. Whilst there is no save function I think I could now probably finish the game in 5-10 minutes (knowing how to do it). That's the fun of the game though. So the lack of saving isn't important.

The game keeps you guessing in many ways, and when you've stopped guessing it lets you finish your investigation into what happened. The ending is pretty fantastic too. I really recomend playing this game when you have a spare hour.

Listen out for the clock chiming, that signals that you can do something knew (even if it's clicking on the picture on the table again). Which will likely then trigger more things to do as well.

HAVE FUN!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: I went in with pretty low expectations and saw all there is to offer in about half an hour or so. This is one of the few games I've played that caused a genuine emotional response. Do yourself a favor and give it a half hour or so; it's more than worth your time. To say any more would hurt the experience.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Amazing game. It does an excellent job at making the player wonder what happened and also what will happen next. The immensely good voice acting ensured the emotions were portrayed powerfully enough to invest me into it - a plain text version would have nowhere near the same effect. I also have no complaints about the graphics or sounds; they all did their jobs perfectly. The camera and player control are reminescent of Myst (albeit updated to today's standards) and will feel odd, if not flat out annoying, to a percentage of players, especially the ones who aren't familiar with old adventure games, since it doesn't allow for 100% free roaming. I myself found it to be a plus, since the fixed positions allowed for the ideal visualization of objects which, in this game, contributes to the emotional connection.\nIf you have between half an hour to one full hour to spare and are into story over gameplay" kind of games
date: then I very much recommend you try this game."

reviewText:
Wow.
All I can say is, Wow.
If you dont want spoilers then stop reading and play the game.  Its a FREE download and is about 30 long (give-er take)

Serena and you are happily married, or so you (the husband) say you are.  One day the husband wakes up and Serena is nowhere to be seen.  There is a photo of you and her on the table, but her face, is smudged out.  You do what you would do in ANY adventure game and CLICK ON EVERYTHING!!  You must desperately search for something, Anything, that will remind you of what she looked like.  When you finally remember her face you look back at the picture, but, she doesn't look happy.  She's kinda frowning.  Clicking on more objects prompts the husband to to remember the, slightly less, good times.  After that you take another good look at the photo you see that her frowning intensified.  Going around the room another time make the Husband remember the bad times and going so far as to curse out his wife saying that she was horrible and its all her fault that there were problems with there relationship.

After that.  The Creepy side of the game starts to reveal itself.

You walk over to your closet and look inside.  You find a Corpse.  Decaying.  It looks like its been there for months.  The husband suddenly starts to think did I
date: kill Serena?" "Was I so mad at her for some reason that it drove me to kill her?"  As you click around the cabin some more the Husband starts to contemplate his actions and what he could do with the body.  As he stumbles around his home he hears people talking.  He thinks its the police but when he walks up to the Curtain drawn windows he sees shadows of 2 people talking about what they should do with the "evidence".  This results in them burning down your cabin with you trapped inside.  THE END!!\n\nIt took me a while to figure it out but YOU are the Corpse in the Closet and the 2 people outside are Serena and her New Lover.  Serena killed you and hid your body in the closet and burned down the house to hide the murder.  You are simply your "spirit"
recommended: or whatever you want to call it
hoursPlayed: Observing the horror from beyond.\n\nBut that's JUST my thoughts on it.  There may be more to this story than I thought..."

reviewText: Free -- can't beat free.\nAlbeit short, this game accomplished more than what most 60$ single release games cannot accomplish with 125 hours of gameplay.  It was a simple concept, click around, you uncover a story as you go, diving deeper and deeper as the story unfolds.  Great ambiance, the mood/tone, voice acting was all really spot on which is hard to find in 'blockbuster' games these days.  Will you spend 500 hours playing Serena?  Not at all.  Will you regret the time you do?  I don't believe so.

reviewText: Serena is a simple and free click-and-point adventure game, the adventure of size of log cabin and of lenght of hour at most. As you can guess, it's a dark story with no clear objective, just hero trying to remember his life with wife by searching there. No worries, there are no jumpscares. You navigate through the log cabin by pointing and clicking and then search various items by pointing and clicking too, resulting in main character commenting on them, most of comments being linked to his wife - Serena.\n\nThe game itself is supposed to be like a tutorial" for upcoming developer's title "Asulym"

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The gameplay in this game consists of walking around a large room inside a cabin in the woods and clicking on objects to hear the character's commentary.  That's it.  There's no real gameplay.  Having said that, it was very interesting to me to hear all of his comments.  There were a surprisingly large number of comments for each object before he started repeating himself.  Then after hearing everything for all objects, he remembered something and then there were new comments on all of the objects with a slightly different tone and more detail, and then he remembered something else, and it repeated a few times with me going around the room clicking on all of the objects until he repeated himself, and then doing it all over again.  By all rights that should be boring, but after a few minutes I was very caught up in the story and trying to piece everything together to figure out what happened.  It was also amazing how much detail came across about his character as well as Serena's just from natural-sounding comments on various objects in their cabin.  Considering it's free, I think it's definitely worth a download and give it a few minutes to absorb the atmosphere and setting to see if you like the story :)

reviewText: Creepy, best way I can describe. Not your everyday game. Pretty much you just check every item in cabin until its over. As boring as it sounds it is a game that should be tried considering it only take an hour to finish. The story line is dark and mysterious and the ending kinda makes you think about what just happen. With any game that has a semi indirect ending I like to pop it up on google and see what other people think and then come up with my own interpretation of what happened. Also in all honesty I was waiting for something to pop out at me such as what dead space1 did, maybe it was the game was dark and creepy but either way it never happened. I also imagine you have to finish the game in one sit down, so if you only have say half an hour to try it out you should wait till you have a good hour till playing.

reviewText:
I feel like some reviews of this game are made by those who wish to align themselves with anything that isn't action-oriented, as if by osmosis they become more nuanced and deep as game players. Whilst you should certaily try this (it's free)  and I have given it a positive review, the game is not some artistic masterpiece others make it out to be.

A lot of the dialogue and writing is bubbling with cliche, although some of that is intentional (can't give away too much). There is enough subtlety in clues and visual information to pique your interest - the only time I became stuck was due to my own fault for not picking up on a clue. The game also exudes an unsettling tone very well, causing me to 'feel' the game for a good while after I completed it.

So don't let your expectations be set too high by glowing reviews, play it as an interesting treat to keep you occupied for 40-50 minutes or so.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Serena reminded me a lot of Gone Home with the creepy atmosphere and the whole click and read/listen feature, the fact it was free forced me to play it. The way it's introduced makes it seem like a typical love story, but there is so much more to it. From the moment I started I didn't stop until I fiinished as it is a short gaming experience but yet there is so much put into this outstanding free-to-play game. Even if this costed £5 I would still buy it as it is definately worth the play. The twists and turns in this story are mind-blowing at times and it really does keep you on the edge of your seat as it is such a fanastic storyline with strong  voice-acting and a brilliant plot-twist to keep you wanting more. Beautiful art design and great visuals and a great soundtrack are also what make this game. Only problem is how short the game is but that is pretty much expected as it is free-to-play. 9/10 a must play for any kind of gamer.

reviewText: Serena is one of those games that everyone should experience. The story is a disturbing ride with many ups and downs that ultimately ends in a way that I never saw coming. Although short, Serena had enough content to make me feel a bit sad, scared, very angry, confused and shocked, but at no point did I ever feel bored.\n\nI finished the game in less than an hour and really enjoyed my time with it. I won't go into any details about the story, but I will say that this is one game that will stick with you for a while and the fact that it is free, completely different from anything else that I've played and kept my interest for the entirety of its short length, makes it a game I fully recommend. A 10 out of 10!

reviewText:
Serena is very bright but very dark. It is also very beautiful but very disturbing. Is Serena worth looking into?

If you are into games that are heavily story driven and with great narration, then I would recommend giving Serena a go.

It was enjoyable to play from the start to the finish. I found myself in questions after I had completed it since it tests your emotions and logic. The controls are very simple (point and click) but I highly recommend you play this game with sound on and if possible, with headphones on. This is because the game would feel rather empty or lacking in emotion and atmosphere since the best part about this game is the narration and the music used in this game. If I had any issues with this game, it would be a few minor problems, mainly technical though (game mechanics). Other than that this game is definitely worth giving a try.

Pros:
- Narration is the strong point of this game and with that in mind, the writer did an amazing job with the script (words weren't  as boring to listen to).
- Short and simple
- Easy to immerse yourself into the mooding and atmosphere of the game, which makes this another strong point of this game.
- The music truly set the mood to this game.
- VA (Voice Actors) did a great job by putting emphasis their words so that the narration didn't feel empty.
- Good details and features, it was nice to look at from beginning to end.
- Things that weren't really neccessary connected to the story had great detail. You can tell how much love and conflict they felt within the relationship.
- The lamps are so plain but beautiful..
- It's free!

Cons:
- Hitting ESC will close the game automatically, so yes, that means no pausing the game or changing volume in-game (there is the volume mixer outside the game so it can still be adjusted)
- Hitting ESC also means when you go to play again after re-opening, you'll have to start from the beginning
- Movement is clicking, it may not be as bad but you need to move to other areas to interact with certain objects
- The photo (yeah the photo) was... ..well you can find out.

reviewText: While short and somewhat predictable I think Serena has been executed very well. I enjoyed the music and while both voiceacting and graphics are not perfect I found them to be really nice and fitting nevertheless. The restraints in terms of controls and location actually seem to contribute to the introverted, anxious atmosphere that the game succesfully tries to convey. If it were to be a true adventure game more freedom and exploration would most certainly have been required, but as a short interactive story it works. Add the fact that it's completely free and runs on Windows as well as on Mac and Linux and there is little left to complain about, really. Try it.

reviewText: It will probably take you less than an hour to discover the reasons behind the repressed memories, and there’s a very solid chance you might well figure it out long before it’s revealed, but the inventive chronicle is well worth experiencing for the radically different and fresh elements it injects in a genre decades old.  Serena largely benefits from its brevity, taking a small collection of elements from a fixed location and slowly perverting them all towards the writer’s grand goal by not just subverting their meaning, but allowing them a small, private history of their own.  It’s storytelling through re-exploration and viewing identical scenarios through differing emotional veneers.\n\nFull review -- http://www.honestgamers.com/12184/pc/serena/review.html

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Serena isn't a game as you might normally think of one, rather it's more of an interactive short story.

A man sits in his cabin in the woods, wondering where his wife is, and struggling to recall her face. Exploring the cabin uncovers emotional attachments and fragments of their story, gradually building a fuller picture of what happened. While playing you'll no doubt be guessing what the truth is - perhaps you'll be spot-on, perhaps miles off or perhaps, like me, correct, but with a twist. Whichever it is you're sure to enjoy finding out.

Serena is a short but affecting and emotive experience, and is very much worth the hour or so of your time it'll take to play it.
I look forward to any further projects from the creative team behind this.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Unlike most free-to-play games, Serena is absolutely, totally free. All of the game's features are available for free. No microtransactions, no unaccessible game content. The game is a nice, short, and sweet experiment -- a good concept for something bigger and better. Unfortunately, one is left with wanting more of everything and feeling dissatisfied with what was given. The plot is short and experienced almost exclusively through the main character's own voice. I was hoping for a more dynamic story, or at least a more meaningful conclusion. A better and bigger game of the same type would need a very deep and dynamic story to keep players interested considering the great lack of depth in the setting.

The graphics are very basic -- good enough for a small laptop, but feel lacking on a larger screen. It has a quality that is reminiscent of Myst, or some of the other mid-90's point-and-click adventure games. Unsurprisingly, one is left wanting better graphics. In addition, the world is very small and that also leaves me wanting more to explore. The audio is unsurprisingly no different than the other game features. It's not good, not terrible, just plain ol' sound -- no high points, no demerits.

At the present, the replay value is essentially zero. But considering that it's totally free, one cannot complain too much about that. I wouldn't even pay 50 cents to play the game, but for free? It's a neat little ride and could be a decent litmus test for a similar, but better developed game in the future.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I feel like some reviews of this game are made by those who wish to align themselves with anything that isn't action-oriented, as if by osmosis they become more nuanced and deep as game players. Whilst you should certaily try this (it's free)  and I have given it a positive review, the game is not some artistic masterpiece others make it out to be.

A lot of the dialogue and writing is bubbling with cliche, although some of that is intentional (can't give away too much). There is enough subtlety in clues and visual information to pique your interest - the only time I became stuck was due to my own fault for not picking up on a clue. The game also exudes an unsettling tone very well, causing me to 'feel' the game for a good while after I completed it.

So don't let your expectations be set too high by glowing reviews, play it as an interesting treat to keep you occupied for 40-50 minutes or so.

reviewText: Serena reminded me a lot of Gone Home with the creepy atmosphere and the whole click and read/listen feature, the fact it was free forced me to play it. The way it's introduced makes it seem like a typical love story, but there is so much more to it. From the moment I started I didn't stop until I fiinished as it is a short gaming experience but yet there is so much put into this outstanding free-to-play game. Even if this costed £5 I would still buy it as it is definately worth the play. The twists and turns in this story are mind-blowing at times and it really does keep you on the edge of your seat as it is such a fanastic storyline with strong  voice-acting and a brilliant plot-twist to keep you wanting more. Beautiful art design and great visuals and a great soundtrack are also what make this game. Only problem is how short the game is but that is pretty much expected as it is free-to-play. 9/10 a must play for any kind of gamer.

reviewText:
It's been a long time since a game has stunned me in ways I thought was impossible...

And then, there's Serena.

The artstyle is fantastic. Although it looks gloomy and gritty, it sets the mood just right and puts attention to detail when needed, you will never miss an item or special event. Although it's nothing fancy, it helps set the mood for this game and it does a bloody good job too.

The gameplay is simple. All you do is click. It may seem a bit too simple but that's the genius part of it. It's so simple that you don't need to worry about controls while playing, which is a brilliant decision.

And finally, the story. Oh. My. ♥♥♥♥ing. God. Even though the story is simple, you can't tell what's going to happen next. I was astounded by the progression of the story and how my character was developing with every move I made. As the plot thickens, you will go on an emotional rollercoaster.

Do I recommend this game? I can't remember...
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Playing Serena may be a disturbing experience, but totally worth if you like psychological thrillers. My take on it (SPOILER ALERT):

What is love? How can love turn into obsession? What separates love from hate? Both are strong feelings that can absorb us completely. This game deals with this question with a simple mechanic: changing descriptions and character’s reaction to examining objects. All you do in the game is examining objects. There is no puzzle, except for a very simple one. Descriptions change (the photo, the poem) once you examine the objects around you, leading you to another psychological level. Nothing around you changes, but the comfortable cabin turns into an oppressive and scary limbo, because your mind changes. That’s the point I guess the game is trying to convey.

Games are the perfect platform to create this dramatic effect. In a movie, it is possible to show exactly the same scene and make it look like a completely different scene using a different soundtrack, for example. But in a game you can do it much better, because the character’s reactions complement the visible scene. The players feel attached to these reactions, taking them as their own, trying to see through the eyes of the character. In this case, not only we know that something changed, but the objects around you are “reframed”, even if they look exactly the same.

Serena also plays with the idea of slowly sliding into insanity. Games are also very good at this, because players can experience this transition on their own pace.

That’s all I have to say. If you played Serena, tell me what think about it. Let me show you that the value of a game is not related to how much time you spend (outside reality) playing it, but how much it can make you think about real things, things that matter. Thank you for reading.

reviewText:
Every once in a while, you need to take a break from the crazy fast paced games that lack any plot. Serena is a great opportunity for that escape. A very beautifully created point and click adventure story featuring a very dirty and gritty but appropriate environment. The plot follows the main character trying to regain some of his memories about his lost wife. The game does a great job at carrying the player through a gambit of emotions as well as helping to progress the story at an increasing accelerated rate.

The game was created using a brand new adventure engine called Dagon developed by the Argentinian studio Senscape. Senscape was founded by the writer and creator of Serena, Agustín Cordes who also created the hit adventure game Scratches.

Overall, if you enjoy story driven adventure games, this game is well worth the time. It was very short but considering the story, the length was perfect. This was just like sitting down to read to a great short story.

If you don't like games that focus on story, this isn't for you. If you want a game that is somewhat like a short scary story, it's definatly worth the download as it's free and worth your time.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This isn't really a game but an interactive experience. You can't fail or lose in this. To progress, you simply click on various items in the cabin to invoke memories of the protaganist regarding his relationship with his wife, Serena. As time passes with you clicking on items (even the same items you clicked on earlier) and exploring around the cabin, the protaganist's emotional state undergoes changes (there are three total emotional stages) until the ending approaches.  The total time taken varies from 40-60 minutes.

The point of Serena is not to have fun. The developers were more concerned with leaving an emotional impact on the gamer. In my opinion, they did a solid job at it because the dialogue and progression of emotional stages of the protaganist made the characters feel real and relatable, thus preparing us for the ending twist. To what extent this game has an impact on you, as with any piece of art, depends on what you make out of the experience as well as your own background in intimate personal relationships.

I really feel that this game is a testament to how video games have the capacity to be great art. It's free and short so I recommend that you try Serena. Take your time in the game. Click on items multiple times for the protaganist to say different things and focus on connecting to the character rather than trying to finish it as fast as you can.
