reviewText:
I somehow magically had this game called Serena already purchased on Steam, and since it was an Indie game I decided to take it for a spin. You play the part of a man who has forgotten why he's in a rustic cabin, and whatever happened to his wife. In this point and click adventure game you will have to reassemble the pieces to discover what you do not know and what you forgot.

Graphically I have to say that this is a very good looking game. I felt like I was in a dusty old cabin, devoid of any true light, but showing that it was lived in, at least at some point, and that the clutter and the items found in the cabin make it all feel real. The only images that I didn't really like was the fact that there were two slightly different hand icons and sometimes made it hard to distinguish between cannot do anything and pick up this item to interact with it.

The sound was probably the hardest thing to pull off about this game, and I have to say that I was impressed. You could feel the emotion in the voices. To be a bit nitpicky I have to say that when the auditory memory flashes of the wife happened I couldn't really picture that voice coming out of the wife, but like I said, nitpicking.

This is not really that long of a game, and to be honest to tell this story it really didn't have to be. There were some very frustrating aspects to this game, most of them revolving around having to touch objects throughout the cabin over and over again trying to pull clues out after you found the last clue spot, but then again we are talking about a man who cannot remember a thing of why he is in the cabin, and where his wife is, so I can understand that as puzzle pieces fall into place, going back over something that meant nothing at first could make a hell of a difference later.

Now as far as I can tell, as of right now the game is free, I'm not sure if that will change, it was released at the end of January 2014, so take it as you would have. I do have to say that I was impressed by the fact that there seemed to be a lot of collaborators taking part in this, but at the same time I don't think it really shows, maybe with everyone adding their two cents and refining details it made it better, but it's hard to tell. Alright so lets give this game a grade shall we? Even though it was short, and there were some frustrating parts to it, once I started the game I literally did not stop until I got to the end, so for that this game gets an 8.9 out of 10.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

The players feel attached to these reactions, taking them as their own, trying to see through the eyes of the character. In this case, not only we know that something changed, but the objects around you are “reframed”, even if they look exactly the same.

Serena also plays with the idea of slowly sliding into insanity. Games are also very good at this, because players can experience this transition on their own pace.

That’s all I have to say. If you played Serena, tell me what think about it. Let me show you that the value of a game is not related to how much time you spend (outside reality) playing it, but how much it can make you think about real things, things that matter. Thank you for reading.

reviewText:
I am only recommending this game because it is free. If it weren't free, I wouldn't recommend spending more than $2 on it.

This is an extremely short game.

You are confined to a small cabin and wander around in circles clicking things (the same things) over and over again until the story resolves. There are no puzzles or adventures.

While it looks nice and they put effort into it, the writing is not realistic, more like things people would say in a romance novel. The ending was unexpected though.

I also found it boring to keep clicking on the same things repeatedly to get the story.

reviewText: This was a fairly incredible, although short, game.  It's fully exploration-based and takes the player on an emotional 360 through the narrator's past with his absent wife.  The ambiance of the cabin changes as the memories unfold, along with the tone of the background music.  It really paints the emotions into your mind as you play, setting you up for some pretty interesting plot-twists as you go.\n\nHighly recommended, as it only takes a short time to play and is free.  You get a decent lot for your time.  I personally was a little traumatized by the ending, but I feel it's a mark of a good game when it can leave you saying wow..." for a little while after you're done."

reviewText:
This comment is neutral.
The story is really simple: a man who doesn't remember anything about his wife Serena and he lives all alone in the house that they lived together in the past. All the game is inside this little house where pointing and clicking every single object inside the house you are able to rebuild all the story between the protagonist and Serena (and of course i will not reveal the final).
As a horror game it was in my opinion little bit aseptic: you can see the circle of the feelings of the protagonist (love-anger-disperation-depression) but i think are not really good connected to each other and as a player i wasn't able to feel the connections between them inside my mind. The only moment where i can found a connection is only when you are pointing and clicking some objects (with a particular order) without trasport the player FOR REAL into the deeps of the protagonist's mind.
About the graphic and the music nothing to say: i think they were good.
Graphic design is dark but simple and related with the atmosphere of the house. The same thing is for the music: easy going and good with the atmosphere of the game. But nothing to be surprised or something that said to you oh wow! This is great! Make me feels distressed as the protagonist!".
The gameplay as a point-and-click is really simple

reviewText:
10/10 I won't get married. Ever.

A very nice psycho-thriller game made by a bunch of people that does its job remarkably; it's job being keeping you in different  states of mind (sad, agitated, nostalgic, reflective about your past\current love stories), then scaring you a little, then dropping the bomb and finally twist your mind.
A great piece of art in the videogame universe that will probably leave a scar in your thoughts.
The graphic is nothing impressive;it's what you could expect from an indie company. Nevertheless it's not bad.
Voice acting is quite convincing.
But it's in the script that this game really shines.

The only con is could find in this game is that some clues that could have helped the ending were omitted (or maybe I just didn't find them: for example:  the accomplice was never introduced, the greedy side of someone was mentioned but could have been emphasized

Looking forward for more games from Senscape.

reviewText:
This was a pleasant little diversion a few nights ago, when I couldn't sleep and was looking for something free and a little creepy to play. It's difficult not to spoiler it, but I'll do my best.

The entire story (about an hour long) takes place inside a cabin, so there's a deliciously claustrophobic element (but not to the point where - if you're claustrophobic, as I happen to be -you'll be panicking while searching for something. This isn't a Skyrim delve). As the mood gradually changes, you begin to realise that you're going to uncover something unpleasant.

It was at this point in the game when I got my jumpscare, when my husband farted in his sleep.

A fun little game with some interesting psychological elements, and 10/10 I'd jump at my husband's sleep fart again.

reviewText:
A psychological horror point&click game, Serena is actually one of those free indie games that are much better than you would expect them to be. The game is short, but it took a very smooth approach at storytelling, has nice graphics and quality of sound, and mainly - the wonderful atmosphere, one of the key points of which - the steady narration of the story. It would be nice to see this game growing into something bigger, extending the story and gameplay into a full-scale game. There are a few downturns (listed them lower), but the game isn't long enough for them to be significant. And yes, this is an absolute recommendation. Enjoy the game.

+ Good story
+ Good sound
+ Excellent artwork
+ Excellent narration
+ Atmosphere of a well-written book

- Sometimes can be a little confusing in terms of progressing.
- The game is a little buggy and it crushed for me a few times.
- Doesn't have the save option, so if you quit, you should start it all over again (but it is fairly short).

reviewText: Serena is more like an interactive story than your standard game. The style is reminiscent of games like Dear Esther, or other relatively surreal, story driven games. Serena details the struggles of a husband who has all but forgotten the details of his wife. Exploring the one-room cabin yields the details of their lives. The narrative is especially good in that it feels very human. While I did not love the voice acting to death, it still conveyed the emotions of the husband to the player very well. Visually, the game is at least decent, although some of the moving transitions feel awkwardly blended. As the game is free, there is no reason not to give it a try and experience it first-hand.

reviewText:
Sorry King Graham, but your Princess is in another cabin.

Ok the first thing I noticed about Serena is that it's a game, the second thing I noticed was that I should click on things, having clicked I was then rewarded by King Graham talking into my ear holes.

It would be easy to at first to dismiss Serena as a throwaway game, but it is a lovely story, that will take your brain from your head, dip it in acid, and then lovingly put it back into your skull to deal with the ♥♥♥♥s it doesn't give about what you think is going on.

All joking aside the team really did a nice job crafting an interesting short (story) game, its as if Poe wasn't lazy being all dead, not knowing what a computer is... PFFT!!

The voice acting was great, Josh Mandel AKA King Graham did a great job as our guide to the lonely cabin, the subtle changes in his character are perfectly done.

After you play this game it will stick with you, and bounce around in your head a while.. exactly the way other games like Angry Birds doesn't.

reviewText: Serena is more like an interactive story than your standard game. The style is reminiscent of games like Dear Esther, or other relatively surreal, story driven games. Serena details the struggles of a husband who has all but forgotten the details of his wife. Exploring the one-room cabin yields the details of their lives. The narrative is especially good in that it feels very human. While I did not love the voice acting to death, it still conveyed the emotions of the husband to the player very well. Visually, the game is at least decent, although some of the moving transitions feel awkwardly blended. As the game is free, there is no reason not to give it a try and experience it first-hand.

reviewText: At first I thought it was slow, and I was looking at the same things over and over, but after finishing it I realise it was pacing it brilliantly. There is tension provoking factors dotted throughout, making you constantly on edge; I was with my sister when I played it, but I was still frightened (I found myself frightened to look at the picture a few times). I won't ruin the ending, but the image of the big reveal is definately one you won't forget soon, for a free game this is positively worth a go. Plus, I recomend reading the names of the books, since they made me giggle.

reviewText: Serena is a very interesting take on the horror genre. It relies on a story telling element rather than fear tactics to induce the player in its setting. Depending on how you play it, you can beat the game in as little as 10 minutes, but on average you'll spend about 30 minutes to an hour playing though the story. The only bone I have to pick with this game is the fact that it literally throughs you in blind and clueless leaving you to do tons of searching around for triggers that progress the story. That being said, the story makes up for the searching. As the story goes on, your attitude towards Serena changes dramatically and it eventually leads to an incredible ending. Overall, if you like adventure/horror games and have an hour to kill, there is no reason not to play this game.\n\n

reviewText:
How do I put this without spoiling anything at all?

Well, let met start from the top: Serena is story driven. Heavily story driven. A first person explorer, you play a nameless man in a cabin trying to piece together memories of his relationship with his supposed wife, the titular Serena. To do that, you must explore and click on items and objects in the tiny cabin.

The game is simply an interactive horror mystery novel and seems simplistic, but the writing is of a calibre alongside Poe and Lovecraft. Josh Mandel delivers a brilliant performance as the protagonist, and the story will grip you to the very, very end. There's simply no reason to not play this game and experience its story. It's enough to give one chills, and plenty to make one ponder.

reviewText:
Sorry King Graham, but your Princess is in another cabin.

Ok the first thing I noticed about Serena is that it's a game, the second thing I noticed was that I should click on things, having clicked I was then rewarded by King Graham talking into my ear holes.

It would be easy to at first to dismiss Serena as a throwaway game, but it is a lovely story, that will take your brain from your head, dip it in acid, and then lovingly put it back into your skull to deal with the ♥♥♥♥s it doesn't give about what you think is going on.

All joking aside the team really did a nice job crafting an interesting short (story) game, its as if Poe wasn't lazy being all dead, not knowing what a computer is... PFFT!!

The voice acting was great, Josh Mandel AKA King Graham did a great job as our guide to the lonely cabin, the subtle changes in his character are perfectly done.

After you play this game it will stick with you, and bounce around in your head a while.. exactly the way other games like Angry Birds doesn't.

reviewText:
If you have some time to waste, this game takes about half an hour to an hour tops to complete. When I started, I was hoping for a little more, maybe the ability to move without the use of point-and-click, though it was alright for what the game is. Felt a bit repetitive from clicking on each thing nearly over and over again, but as the story went on, it felt more interesting to get what he was thinking about, and why.

The atmosphere was nice, that dreadful feeling as you keep going was perfect.

At the beginning I already guessed what had happened (I was right), and I'm sure a lot of other people will be able to as well. It's a kind of predictable story, but a lot of it is missing so we sort of piece together what happened ourselves.

An interesting collaboration, but I guess I shouldn't have wished for a lot out of a free game. Still nice, though, kudos to those who created it. The ending was a bit unclear but maybe that's how they wanted it.

reviewText:
Serena is a great point and click adventure story that I'm happy to have downloaded for free.   Execellent work on the story, voice acting, mood setting atmosphere, music and sounds that creep in just at the right moment...  The game is very short and sweet, and quite frankly easy to complete on your first try, but I may have missed a few extra sceens and narration.  Because of this, I'll have to play through it again and see what all I missed the first time, so I guess you could say there's some replayability factor.

If you have the 317mb or so of free disc space to download the game, and you'd like point and click adventure story with the sad/creepy and confined mood resembling that of Silent Hill 4: The Room (when you're in The Room anyways...), then I highly recomend downloading Serena and playing through it at least once.

Great job to the crew that created Serena!  Make more stuff!  Free stuff!  :)

reviewText:
It's a Very Short and Very misleading-Thought Provoking Psychological Thriller game.

It's not hardcore horror to be honest, just plain creepy and kinda emotional upto an extent.
The scariest thing about this game is expecting something scary to happen but it never happens.
Also this one emphasized that sometimes, when you forget something it's not because you forgot, it because you wanted to forget.

If i were to compare the narration and the voice acting, i'd say that the female voice actress did a great job than the male one but overall it was fine. It's dramatic,poetic and all that hullabaloo was there to make it intense but because it's short it failed to give out what i really wanted to feel. The art was dark.. I'd defend it saying that it was made that way to give out that depressing creepy atmosphere.

The game mechanics are what you percieve in a normal HOG game, creepy atmosphere but not creepy enough. The paintings terrified me and I was away from them most of the time. It needed more interaction with items,combining them and using them. Would have been good if i could have gotten out of the cabin or at least a secret trap door, but then yeah the plot required it to be that way so no complains there.

I'm already used to the esc key booting you out of the game instead of making you go to the title because of PCSX2 so no rage there.
Oh and the best plot twist ever and should play it again tonight.

Erotic but not Obscene" the man said XD"

reviewText:
I'm a little torn on this one. For the cost there's a pretty nice amount of content, especially considering the game is free. It just isn't that much fun. Even at a free price I just didn't enjoy my time with this short game.

One of the big things is that the voice acting isn't that good. It can be nice at times, but for the most part it's pretty passable at best. The other thing is that it's a little bit frustrating to have to click on the same couple of items over and over and over again to get the story to move ahead a bit. The plot is predicatable too.

The best way I can describe this is a cable tv version of Silent Hill. It's tame enough that it can be enjoyed by most audiences, but is limited in how well it can tell its story because of it. I don't really recommend this one. There's better stories out there to sit with. It isn't the worst story in the world, and it can be engaging now and then, it just isn't that engaging.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game so much. There are so many good things about it-but unfortunately it all fell apart for me pretty quickly.
When the game opens, the cabin is perfect-its bleak, oppresive, and dark. The details are wonderful, as is the curiosity and anticipation that it brings. When your character starts narrating, I was able to overlook  the terrible voice acting at first. I was still in awe at the atmosphere, and hanging onto the reviews that some gaming sites gave the game. To clarify, I'm not sure that it is just because he did a terrible job, but his actual voice was not proper for this story. It just didn't sound believable-at all.
While this started to frustrate me, I became more frustrated with the idea of having to click the same items over and over and over and over again. I am not exaggerating either. There was so much different dialogue for the same damn item. After clicking it until he started to repeat himself, you would think you were done with that item-nope! Walk around the cabin a bit and what seems to be randomly, the same item elicits different dialogue, and then again, and again, and again. Are you getting the idea yet?
To ice the cake, there is no pause, and if you try to pause it via hitting the escape button (like every other game's menu/pause normally pops up) it will close the game, and you have to start all over again! Seriously? Now I understand this game was free and I really do appreicate developers that work their a$$ off to bring us cool free stuff. I can also tell that a lot of work went into this game. Sadly it fell flat with a jumbled story, that consisted of WAY too much dialogue, that was poorly narrated. I was so very disapointed, because this game could have been SO much more =(

reviewText:
Serena is a short free exploration game.
You take the role of Serenas husband, who is been waiting in a secluded cabin for her return. But you appear to have some memory problems.  You do not know how long you have been waiting for her. But as you continue to explore your little cabin, you start to realize that maybe there is a reason she is gone.
The colorless graphics are perfect for telling this kind of story, which gets creepier and creepier,
The sounds are just the bare necessities like creaking floorboards, ticking clocks and of course: the voice acting (which is not bad).
The controls are very simple.  You move your mouse around & click on various objects to hear the husband narrate various thoughts & memories.  He will have multiple things to say about nearly everything you find in the house.  As you examine the right combination of items to trigger key memories, things in the cabin will start to change, unlocking new memories & objects to examine until you uncover the truth.
The game is very short, it takes less than an hour if you listen to everything.
Serena is a short and simple game, but somehow kind of beautiful.
If you have spare time and do not know what you could play, you could try Serena but don't expect too much.

Sounds 7/10
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 2/10
Atmosphere 6/10

reviewText:
Warning: Spoilers below.

An average game. It can take less than 1 hour, and that is actually a lot, considering it starts and ends in such a small place. Everything you need to play this is a mouse, nothing else. Rather than just finishing it, Serena tries to focuse you on its story:

You remember you had a wife, but you don't have any other memories of her other than that - you can't even imagine her face. In order to remember her again, you will have to examine various mementos around the house that will uncover more than just your wife's face...
What makes this story interesting is something that you will see once you start making progress. I would say, it is decent, and reminds me of one of my favorite games, Silent Hill 2.

In addition, if you stand still for a small period of time, you will receive a hint in where you should look.

Aesthetically, the game doesn't really reveal anything new; the graphics, although not bad, could've used a bit more of detail. I actually liked how the house is made out of wood, almost fully painted with faint brown. It resembles the real nature of the protagonist in some way.

But there are some points within the game that affect it negatively.
They aren't exactly bugs, but issues that can be improved.
These points are:

1. No pause screen. Pressing escape will just close the game without saving any progress you could've made. There isn't even a start menu, and Serena will automatically shut itself down once the credits end.

2. Voice acting is below average. Regardless of the surprises you go finding throughout the game, the protagonist seems to be barely surprised at all. A special example is when you open the closet.

3. Fading texts. Once you finish a speech from any element, and yet you click again to keep the speech going, it will restart. Since you can always keep clicking to repeat it, the fact that subtitles fade after some period of time becomes a problem, as they can block your view with ease.

Last of all:

There's also this: It relies on you if you want to play the game until the very end; while the story is well-thought, the gameplay can still become very boring after a short time, specially if you get stuck; in order to progress you would have to pay special attention to what the protagonist says about each object. Going through that process is not pleasing.

Overall, Serena is not bad, but would need a bit more of polishing.

It's still a good title to spend time on; it's also free to play.

I recommend it.

reviewText:
I'm going to be honest, I'm not a fan of point-and-click games. I hate the feeling that I can't really control what the character is doing. Horror games are the worst, getting away with cheap jumpscares that you have no control of. Serena was an exception.

Serena is not a horror game. It is not scary...but it does give off an eerie, yet appropriate, feeling as you stumble around the cabin.

You walk around your decaying cabin, discovering items that spark memories back into you. Where is Serena? What did she look like? I can't quite remember...

The quiet that you face in the cabin (with the exception of a ticking clock) is unsettling. Our protagonist slowly makes connections that ultimately lead to our solution. However, if you're like me, you've probably figured out what's going on before the game ends.

The game doesn't take that long to play, so if you have half an hour, you should be able to complete it.

The only problem that I believe the game faces is, like most point-and-click adventure games, you may reach a point where you have no idea what to do. You've clicked on everything ten times over and are running around trying to find the next connection. (The game features different dialouge on the same items, so you could click a chair three times and get a different response from our protagonist) Other than that, this game is worth your time, especially since it is free.

Serena is a short exploration game with emphasis on narrative design. As opposed to Gone Home, which brought many haters due to its price tag, Serena is completely free, so nobody can complain here. reviewText:
I find this game as if it is trying to be like: Dear Esther, which is still one of my favorite games to pick up on a cloudy day... But this game, doesn't necesarily do anything wrong... but they do a lot of things, for lack of a better term, lacking in potential. It feels an awful lot like a Twilight Zone episode, building up a plot of a man and a wife, who live in a cabin in the middle of the woods. The man is a introvert while the wife, you don't really get to learn too much about her character (minus the main character is her husband) except that she is unhappy with something. The man's unconciderate personality, living in books and studies, ignores what her attempts to tell him why she was this way.
The story picks up as you try and find out where your wife is, while never leaving the cabin... Then, to add to more problems, you get to keep clicking on random objects around the house - over and over and over again... Given, that practically every time that you do click on it, it does say somehting new... But it is clicking after clicking after clicking...
This game went for a psycheological aproach where it messes with the main character's mind and he becomes ever more angry at the sittuation and the objects in the room. But it does it to the point where you need to keep revisiting objects in order to piece together a memory that may give reason to where the character's wife is.
There were no glitches or crashes when I played through the game, so that is plus wihtout being said.
At the end of the game I felt displeased. Entertained. But displeased needless to say.
I played the game through but whether it has alternate endings or not, I did not find it worth my time to go back and play through the game, again.

It is a descent one time play-through"
date: but I am glad that it was free...\nI'd barely give it a 2/5"

reviewText:
For a free game that you can complete in under an hour, I enjoyed Serena. It's an adventure game that really plays out like a visual novel. There are no puzzles, just lots and lots of story that you have to uncover in a fairly linear order to reach the end. You'll be clicking on the same objects over and over to hear new observations and revelations from the first-person narrator.

The story itself is interesting, though not completely original or surprising. If you're like me you'll guess how the game is going to play out within the first few minutes and be pretty much correct. That said, the story is presented in such a way that the journey is still enjoyable. The voice acting is pretty well done which is good, because otherwise the game would not have been effective. The sound design and music also help to build some creepy tension in the right places.

I recommend spending a dark and depressing hour with Serena.

reviewText:
This game really surprised me. At first, noticing its a point and click, made me think ''ok it might be ok but will probably get boring pretty fast'' but the story sucked me in!

Basically youre a man in a cabin who is depressed and missing his wife who has mysteriously left and you are unsure of why she left or if she is coming back. You start completely confused, not knowing what is happening. The man you are seems very confused and has trouble remembering the events that have happened, so you must explore and examine every aspect of the cabin, finding objects that begin unlocking memories, which then lead to more examination opportunities. Eventually your mood as the character goes from depressed to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and angry. Then the story takes a huge twist and the ending is wonderful.

The graphics were well done for a point and click game. The twist and the graphic nature of it actually made me feel his emotions, which was great. If a game can make me feel as crazy and sad as this guy feels about what hes finding out, you won my vote lol. I don't need great graphics or amazing gameplay. Its the story and impact of emotions.

Well done! Hope to see more in the future.

reviewText:
Protip: The Esc button does not open a menu, it closes out the game!

This game completely took me by suprise.  I love point and click games because they make me feel like a snoop.  The main character tells you different things about all the items that he can interact with.  Memories associated with them.  It seemed a little dull at first and then that quickly changed.  This game is very psychological.

You're in a cabin that's basically one large room.  There are several things that you can look, drawers to open and look through.  The atmosphere really fits as the game progresses.  Little things that he says that seemed unimportant begin to have more of an impact as you start to recover memories alongside him.  Not to mention there are only two peices of artwork in the cabin.  I'll let you see those for yourself.

There are some funny parts to the dialouge at times.  The bookshelf is one of my favorite points of interest.  The titles are hilarious and if you click a few times to get him to speak at one point he says I didn't lend out my copy of the Necronomicon did I?"  If any of you have played the game Scratches take note of the easter egg in the second shelf.  There is a book that will look familiar that is laying on top of the other books.

I'll certianly be playing through it again to see if there is a different ending
date: or if I missed anything.  Bottom line
recommended: this game is a great way to spend an hour.  And it's free.  There is no reason not to pick it up.\n"

reviewText:
This game is something... special. It's free, and overall is amazing. Great music, great story. Throw in a few achievments and trading cards and I'd even consider buying it. However, it has big pluses and big minuses. On the up side, the music is great, the story is great, and in terms of point and click, there no stupid puzzles. One part or two parts felt predictable, but turned out differently than expected.
There's a lot to explore and alot of content to such a small and impactful game - great, but some of the things aren't defined from other objects and are almost pixel-hunt feeling, which can means you can easily end up missing a few things - bad.
The voice acting, although good, is just that. Good. Not great, which drew me back slightly since everything else is done very well. Also, I guess it's supposed to feel like you're pacing around a cabin, but it just starts to feel repeative. It's buggy, not having an alt+tab feature or any options. Make sure your volume is ok before you start.

Overall amazing game and definitely worth playing, with mostly only mechanical issues being biggest draw back.

But this game, doesn't necesarily do anything wrong... but they do a lot of things, for lack of a better term, lacking in potential. It feels an awful lot like a Twilight Zone episode, building up a plot of a man and a wife, who live in a cabin in the middle of the woods. The man is a introvert while the wife, you don't really get to learn too much about her character (minus the main character is her husband) except that she is unhappy with something. The man's unconciderate personality, living in books and studies, ignores what her attempts to tell him why she was this way.
The story picks up as you try and find out where your wife is, while never leaving the cabin... Then, to add to more problems, you get to keep clicking on random objects around the house - over and over and over again... Given, that practically every time that you do click on it, it does say somehting new... But it is clicking after clicking after clicking...
This game went for a psycheological aproach where it messes with the main character's mind and he becomes ever more angry at the sittuation and the objects in the room. But it does it to the point where you need to keep revisiting objects in order to piece together a memory that may give reason to where the character's wife is.
There were no glitches or crashes when I played through the game, so that is plus wihtout being said.
At the end of the game I felt displeased. Entertained. But displeased needless to say.
I played the game through but whether it has alternate endings or not, I did not find it worth my time to go back and play through the game, again.

It is a descent one time play-through"
date: but I am glad that it was free...\nI'd barely give it a 2/5"

reviewText:
This is a free-game and it is very short, just about one hour of gameplay. It is a first person point of view and all you will do is point, click, and hear/read everything the character say/think.

The minimalism of this game coupled with the intense stream of consciousness, that immerses us in a feeling of suspense, reminded me a little bit of Hitchcock's films. Its minimalis opposes and juxtaposses with the grandiosity of the work (a work of art, indeed) just as the way as the Master of Susupense.

The entire game is in a cabin. The main character barely have memories about his lovely wife, Serena, and he made everything that is possible to remind what did happen between them. As he recalls all the events of their relationship, the history guides us to an creepy climax and a great ending.

I think this game can, and must, be used as a good approch of the common player to artistic games like Dear Esther, Dinner's Date and The Path, for exemple.

Now, I can only thank the developers for having it available this masterpiece for free. It is a great gift, indeed. I would pay for a game like this.

reviewText: A story of two people who met and fell in love, but then life happened to them. reviewText: The psychological aspect behind this interactive story (keep in mind there's no actual gameplay) is conducted in such a way that will make you wonder and think. The time it takes for you to finish is less than an hour but the time it takes for you to stop thinking about the ending and the entire story itself is more than a week. If you're looking for a horror game with jumpscares, loud sounds, and combat, Serena" is not for you. The reason it's classified as "horror" is because of the way the player can perceive the story and events that take place. Immersing yourself in the story can and will cause chills to be sent down your spine
recommended: and maybe even fear. I would definitely reccomend this game if you're the kind of person more interested in the "psychological horror" category."

reviewText:
This is a one hour interactive point and click adventure. It is a 2d environment, let's call it some kind of virtual tour through photospherical pictures...like google street view. Many old adventures were like this back in the day (often without even being able to look around). This makes a great laptop or tablet game....you don't require any power at all.

The voice acting is amazing, such voices could easily be in a AAA game. The story is wonderful narrated but is mysterious enough to let you interpretate it. The game has the 'horror' tag but is not the kind of horror that tries to scare you. You will see while playing, but if you can't play games like outlast or amnesia (I cannot...), don't worry, this game has nothing to do with that kind of 'scary'.

And it's free....I've seen much worse stuff where they asked 10 euros. This is an entertaining little free game.

reviewText:
This game is something... special. It's free, and overall is amazing. Great music, great story. Throw in a few achievments and trading cards and I'd even consider buying it. However, it has big pluses and big minuses. On the up side, the music is great, the story is great, and in terms of point and click, there no stupid puzzles. One part or two parts felt predictable, but turned out differently than expected.
There's a lot to explore and alot of content to such a small and impactful game - great, but some of the things aren't defined from other objects and are almost pixel-hunt feeling, which can means you can easily end up missing a few things - bad.
The voice acting, although good, is just that. Good. Not great, which drew me back slightly since everything else is done very well. Also, I guess it's supposed to feel like you're pacing around a cabin, but it just starts to feel repeative. It's buggy, not having an alt+tab feature or any options. Make sure your volume is ok before you start.

Overall amazing game and definitely worth playing, with mostly only mechanical issues being biggest draw back.

reviewText:
This is a very different point and click. At least different to any I've seen. I quite enjoyed this game but i wouldn't call it a horror game, it's more... creppy. I do like that creepy painting that you see in the screen shots. I really had to nitpick to find issues with this game.

Good stuff first:
I liked this game, not because it's fun but because it felt more like a book or short indi film. The game is story heavy and you have to peace it togeather yourself considering you have no memory of what happened... like in Amnesia: the dark decent... moving on! The overall graphics are great, i saw no flaws nor breaks in textures, This really helped my immersoin thoughout the game. Hell, even the light is god damn beautiful. Graphics can make or break a game, so to see the devs do such a great job is an experiance in itself. The sounds and overall music are good even though I didn't pay much attention. I mean, you make up your own mind about this game. No really, this game is free, just go play it.

Now the not so good stuff:
This was the first thing i picked up on: controls and movment, I know this point an click but moving around is like those old Escape the Room flash game, this really annoys me. Not only that but the mouse feels reall floaty, and I mean like you're moving it underwater. Fortunatly they have the option to use the WASD keys to look around... yeah those are worse then the mouse. I'm not going to get strated on the WASD contorls, but there's one more thing: the main character. Holy crap biscuts he's insensitive, so insenitive he forgets what his own wife looks like. Talk about cold hearted. Not only that but if you click on something enought he'll go into a loop of things he's said. this isn't normally a bad thing but if your game is this story heavy at least make him say something like: I've nothing more to say about this
date: \n\nOverall: go play this game even if you aren't a fan of point and clicks or horror" game. Really I feel it's just plain old creepy. You're alone in a dusty old cabin somewhere in the forest with slight amnesia... Either I give this four out of five creepy paintings. Oh and before i forget... she's standing right behind you..."

reviewText:
Serena offers a compact, slowly darkening tale of one man's relationship and its progress over time, as told by a cabin full of his memories of their time together. Despite being constrained to only a couple of rooms' worth of space, the tale that unfolds as you pore over mementos is touching, thought-provoking, and more than a little bit scary come its climax.

Under the premise of waiting for your wife for a romantic weekend at your cabin retreat, your character begins reminiscing about his time in his marriage, rolling off anecdotes left and right. As these tales go on, subtle changes begin to transform the cabin's interior, revealing new information as you re-inspect things and eventually making it clear that everything is not quite what it seems.

It's difficulty to say much about this without spoiling things, but be sure to keep checking everything over and over; I got hung up for a bit because new stories got tied to the same item rather closely to one another, and I didn't think to check said item a second time so soon.

Even if you do get a bit hung up, Serena is super-short, and given its lack of a save function, the game's clearly meant to be played in one session. It's certainly not anything revolutionary, but given the price, you can't really go wrong with giving it at least one run-through. If anything, I'd recommend more than one, as I'm still not entirely clear on what went down.

reviewText: I'm warning you now this contains spoilers. This is for you sake more than it is mine, because I'm saving you an hour of your time. So this game started oit incredibly weak, then built it's way up. I started to geuinely enjoy it. There were mysteries to be solved. It gave you just enough information to begin piecing things together, but not so much that you had your answer. You play as a writer, name not given, as he patiently awaits his wife at the cabin. The thing that kept me playing was the thing where he would talk about patiently awaiting the love of his life, and occasionally break off into how he missed her so much... How he'd do anything to see her again but realistically knew it couldn't happen. It reminded me a lot of Silent Hill 2, and as a very avid fan of the orignal Silent Hill games, it gave me a damn good feeling. Another thing I enjoyed was the fact that after a while, all this untapped love and immense amounts of nostalgia turned into bitter hate. He talks about burning her clothes, how much he hates her and how vein she is. It turns violent. Fast. Something happened between the main character and his wife Serena. They never really tell you what happens. He talks about pouring salt down her throat until she vomits. Throwing entire bookshelves into the damn lake. You hear the voice of Serena once you look at certain objects; going from sweet and loving to angry and hate filled. Now, before long, after finding a jewelry box in a trunk and setting it down on the wooden table, you have to go to the ama- amair- dammit I don't speak French. You go to the big old dresser right next to the bed and there's a dead body. By the way, Mr. I'm a writer so I have to use unnecesarrily big words" Goes into a horrible fit of rage earlier in the game
date: the likes of which are usually reserved for insulted Russians and Patrick Kane after a cab driver forgot to give him the extra $0.25 to his change from cab fare. (I wouldn't lie to you. Look it up.) So
recommended: you hear voices and there's a dude and a chick. They talk about bulldozers taking down the cabin and how the female left something in the cabin. (I thought it was the body but she said she wore it. I dont think many people can slip into a dead body like it were some type of dress.) The female voice is very obviously Serena. They then set the place on fire and the credits roll
hoursPlayed: leading to a more disappointing ending than Arkham Origins. It also leaves a lot of questions unanswered. Who was the dead body? Who was the stiff Serena was talking to? Why did they set the cabin on fire? Why didn't the main character remember anything? Why was he even in the cabin in the first place? Did Serena invite him there so she could kill him? What bulldozers? Why bulldozers? Why does the same damn spot on the floor make an ungodly amount of creaking sounds? Is there a sercret there? I'm not just being dumb and skipping over things here. I spent an entire hour exploring every possiblity in the game. These questions and more are left unasked. I'll hand it to them though. The creators did do a pretty good job of making an overall somewhat creepy atmosphere. It'd grow oddly darker for no reason. There is a picture of Serena on the table

reviewText: Serena is an Experimental adventure game that promises to raise the bar of how we play adventure games but is it a game you will want to play ? In Serena you play as un un named man who is visint a cabin from his past because he wants to relive the memories of his wife Serena, but then everything goes wrong and the events are darker. But is it any good ? The game is played in a point and click format. Its pretty simple but the game turns complex pretty quickly. The game has no puzzles what so ever and all you do is go around the cabin and click on items to hear the story of the man and Serena. The game is a pretty disturbing journey from the begging to the end. The game has a really eerie atmosphere and it gets disturbing real quick, but the game has many bugs that keep the game from beeing good. Some bugs include you not going where you need to and then when clicking on the items you will not hear the story youre supposed to hear. But the game has great writing that might keep you on the edge of youre seat until the end. reviewText:
I believe the best way to review this game is by responding to some of the features listed for it on the store page. Before I do that though if you're really that curious about it then give it a shot, hell it's free after all and only takes about an hour to finish.

A (twisted) love letter to the adventure game community"
I would hardly call this a love letter to anything
date:
especially the adventure game community. There isn't any adventure to be had in this game and it doesn't seem like anything more than a cheap "spooky" point-and-click flash game with better graphics and alright voice acting.

"Over 40 contributors provided their wit and talents"
I know that contribution can mean a lot of things when it comes to a collaboration but for over 40 people to have included their "wit and talents" this game doesn't seem to show much of either that would help it stand out amongst other decently made one-shot indie games.

"Extremely depressive mood
recommended: and a bit of fear here and there"\nDon't go into this game thinking you will find anything "extreme" here. This game only managed to evoke a simple appreciation for what they were trying to do in terms of atmosphere from me
hoursPlayed:
and never did I feel anything beyond that.

"A haunting story that will challenge your intellect (and temerity)"
If you enjoy the horror/psychological horror genre and can pretty much figure out the cliche ending to any story in said genre before it's given away then chances are nothing will get past
voteText: or interest
helpfulPercent:
you here.

"Did we mention the gut-wrenching atmosphere?"
Yes you did and no it's not."

reviewText:
The story is completely unoriginal (If you have already played Anna, you'll know what this goes about in an instant.. BTW, Anna is a cool game). The game mechanics are stiff, and the game it self is completely linear.

I was hoping for something different, but this game didn't exite me at all.
I finished it just too see it completely, but the experience resulted to be exasperating.

And I DO enjoy games in which story telling is the main factor, but this was just a bad one.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's easy to tell that a lot of effort went into this, but there is 0 gameplay to be had here and as a result it comes off as a pretentious load of crap.

It's being touted as an adventure" game but I disagree with that because real adventure games have some degree of gameplay in the form of puzzle solving usually.

This has nothing
date: you are given a photo and a horrible sounding man and you are made to piece the plot together yourself
hoursPlayed: but there is absolutely 0 reason to give a damn about this guy.  You walk around a log cabin and click things until something happens.  Once all the things happen the games over and at no point are you ever made to feel anything for any of the characters involved.\n\nNo skill or brainpower required for this "game"
voteText: just click until it's over.\n\nIf you want a real adventure game with a vague plot about a man walking around a cabin
helpfulPercent: go and play Anna instead.  However there is a lot of talent on display here so I'll look foward to the day that Senscape make a real game."

reviewText: I only played this because it was free and had good reviews... and I severely regret that choice. It is basically 30 minutes of nothing but the main character describing his wife and looking at a few objects in their home, without any emotion whatsoever. The ending was pretty much what I suspected the entire time, though it really didn't make sense at all...  I usually like detail in games, but this is just boring and pointless, I don't understand how anyone could have enjoyed this.\n\nIf you want to sit and listen to an old, melancholic man muse about his relationship, then I guess this is for you. Personally I want to rake my eyes out from boredom. If this was any longer I could have never finished it.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Serena is a very short and boring game for me. The whole game is centered on two rooms of a winter lodge, and you need to click items on a certain sequence to progress into the game story.
At the end you get the plot, but it leaves you with a question: That was it!? Where is the rest of the game?!?
I've finished it in less than 30 minutes, so just imagine the complexity of it... 5 out of 10 for me, sorry Serena.

reviewText: When reading the reviews, I had high hopes for this game. I honestly have NEVER left a game review, but after wasting my time on this; I felt compelled. I'm so glad it was free because I would be kicking myself if I had paid for it. The plot line was just confusing and trying way too hard. It seemed as if they wanted to be convoluted and edgy, but it was just covoluted and not creative. The plot made little sense, and what sense I could make out of it made for a anti climatic ending. It's a waste of an hour. As far as the horror aspect? Goosebumps: Escape from Horrorland is scary than this game.

reviewText: Wow! This was pretty great. Gameplay consists of exploring a cabin, examining items and letters with narration. I did get a little bored with things towards the end of my first round of the cabin, but the plot promptly kicked in and I was pretty rapt for the rest of the time. Also, this game is freakin' beautiful. Everything is very, very visually-detailed which certainly adds to the player's immersion into the world. Due to the point-and-click nature of the game, it takes relatively little power to run. My playthrough took 76 minutes; I explored the cabin completely during each section of the plot, and watched credits.

reviewText: Oh good lord, this was a fantastic little gem. It starts off so innocently. You play as a guy with very hazy memories, and basically build a clearer picture as you explore further. reviewText: This is a point and click adventure game, but it really is done very well.  The artwork is reasonably good, the voice acting is excellent, and the story is top notch for a free game.  While I don't usually play this kind of game, I really have to recommend this one.  I don't want to give anything away, but the story will compel you to complete the game, and in a stroke of brilliance on the developers' behalf, the environment will adapt to your actions in particular ways.  Very smart plot.  Play this game- it is excellent work for this genre and a bargain for a free release.

reviewText: Serena places you in an old cabin in control of a man that is lost and confused. The main question being: Where is Serena?" Throughout this short exploration game that question is answered in a twist of emotions and memories that will have you empathising with the character. This dark game is very easy to control and displays great writing along with great art and a wonderful turn of events that will not end how you expect
date: I promise you.\n\nGiven that this game is free
recommended: you can expect that it may not deliver much. This game is not such a case. I would recommend this game to absolutely anybody that enjoys exploration/adventure games or those that desire a wonderful story that may leave you with a shiver down your spine.\n\nA fantastic free game."

reviewText:
This game is a trip. It's very short but you can instantly feel this guys emotion in how he loved and hated his spouse and the ending is pretty crazy. It took me a while to even figure out what actually happened. I highly recommend this game for a quick little psychological/emotional trip to see just how bad love can be sometimes.

*SPOILER ALERT*

So yeah to clear up people's confusion - The corpse you find at the end is not your spouses corpse. You didn't kill her as you might have suspected. It's your own corpse. The whole playthrough you are playing as a ghost because she burned you alive while you hid in the closet. Such an evil *itch.

reviewText: This is the perfect answer to all the multi million dollar triple A titles that do not matter in any way whatsoever today. In about 60 minutes one experiences a truly involving and disturbing maelstrom of a story and all that in one (!) little cabin in the woods. But only if you let yourself in on this trip and be at least a little patient and open minded. But once you feel the story twists that are coming around the next corner indicated by little tiny changes (that will definitely fall under your radar if you're not patient and focussed), you won't turn off this game until the credits roll.

reviewText: Played this on a whim; I HAVE to recommend Serena. The game starts off letting the player explore the environment at their own pace, but as more clues come to light, you will start frantically clicking on everything to get the story moving faster, not for lack of pacing but out of curiosity. For something so small, Serena is tightly packed and polished, shining because of the level of player involvement in the pacing.\n\nYou are simply an observer who wants to know the whole story.

reviewText: Wow! This was pretty great. Gameplay consists of exploring a cabin, examining items and letters with narration. I did get a little bored with things towards the end of my first round of the cabin, but the plot promptly kicked in and I was pretty rapt for the rest of the time. Also, this game is freakin' beautiful. Everything is very, very visually-detailed which certainly adds to the player's immersion into the world. Due to the point-and-click nature of the game, it takes relatively little power to run. My playthrough took 76 minutes; I explored the cabin completely during each section of the plot, and watched credits.

reviewText: This is a point and click adventure game, but it really is done very well.  The artwork is reasonably good, the voice acting is excellent, and the story is top notch for a free game.  While I don't usually play this kind of game, I really have to recommend this one.  I don't want to give anything away, but the story will compel you to complete the game, and in a stroke of brilliance on the developers' behalf, the environment will adapt to your actions in particular ways.  Very smart plot.  Play this game- it is excellent work for this genre and a bargain for a free release.

reviewText: Not bad especially since it doesn't cost anything. Also don't press escape, that will automatically close the game, there are no saves, and they don't tell you anything. Besides that, the ambiance and suspense were definitely well done. reviewText:
At its core, Serena is a point and click story game, with the player interacting with objects in order to hear the protagonist deliver his thoughts relating to that item. In this way, the game tells a story through the character's monologue, as he recalls the events which occurred within the cabin the game is based in. Yes, this entire game takes place within a single cabin, and while this may seem limiting, I feel that it's what makes the way the story is delivered so impressive.

The game opens up into the first person perspective of a man sitting in a cabin. There is no menu and there are no options to adjust; the game begins immediately upon launch. I don't feel that this detracted from the accessibility or usability of the game too much (if at all), since the game doesn't really need much customization, though at times, I felt the lighting within the cabin was a bit dark or obscure, and could have appreciated an option to adjust in game brightness.

Serena competently demonstrates that there are many ways to view the same thing. An item is just that; it has no meaning until we give it one, and this is subject to change depending on our experiences.

Voice acting is delivered with appreciable and believable emotion, which really helped me to connect with the mental state of the characters. An equally well done soundtrack only serves to complement the atmosphere and emotion of the game.

Had it not been for the surprisingly engrossing story, Serena would just be another point and click problem solving game, requiring the player to find objects and interact with them in a specific manner or order. The moving story, well delivered audio, and competent writing that has gone into this short game make it one of the better point and click games around. I found myself actually wanting to hear what the character had to say about all the items in the cabin as the story progressed, rather than just trying to find the next trigger to proceed further.

As a free, short, story telling game, Serena is at least worth a look, if not the hour or two you may spend finishing it.

reviewText: This game is a short yet intensely moving point and click adventure. It deals entirely with the relationship between a couple and handles it brilliantly. With just enough information and a simple premise, you are quickly drawn into this bleak world. The script was a little cheesy at first but after a few minutes, you grow accustomed to it and are swept away by its elegance. This is due in no small part to a spot-on delivery by the protagonist/narrator. This is one of the best hours I've spent gaming for quite some time. 10/10

reviewText:
At its core, Serena is a point and click story game, with the player interacting with objects in order to hear the protagonist deliver his thoughts relating to that item. In this way, the game tells a story through the character's monologue, as he recalls the events which occurred within the cabin the game is based in. Yes, this entire game takes place within a single cabin, and while this may seem limiting, I feel that it's what makes the way the story is delivered so impressive.

The game opens up into the first person perspective of a man sitting in a cabin. There is no menu and there are no options to adjust; the game begins immediately upon launch. I don't feel that this detracted from the accessibility or usability of the game too much (if at all), since the game doesn't really need much customization, though at times, I felt the lighting within the cabin was a bit dark or obscure, and could have appreciated an option to adjust in game brightness.

Serena competently demonstrates that there are many ways to view the same thing. An item is just that; it has no meaning until we give it one, and this is subject to change depending on our experiences.

Voice acting is delivered with appreciable and believable emotion, which really helped me to connect with the mental state of the characters. An equally well done soundtrack only serves to complement the atmosphere and emotion of the game.

Had it not been for the surprisingly engrossing story, Serena would just be another point and click problem solving game, requiring the player to find objects and interact with them in a specific manner or order. The moving story, well delivered audio, and competent writing that has gone into this short game make it one of the better point and click games around. I found myself actually wanting to hear what the character had to say about all the items in the cabin as the story progressed, rather than just trying to find the next trigger to proceed further.

As a free, short, story telling game, Serena is at least worth a look, if not the hour or two you may spend finishing it.

reviewText:
Genre: Interactive Fiction

Summary:
A man, following the falling-out with his wife, decides to reflect upon his life.

Pros:
- Beautiful pre-rendered environments and particle effects illustrate the passing of time and instill a melancholy atmosphere.
- Loads of dialogue points for the player to peruse with old interactables sporting new dialogue.
- Short (1-1½ hours), didn't drag on any longer than it had to.

Cons:
- Forwarding the plot isn't always intuitive; becomes guesswork at parts.
- The background music muffles the narrator in a late segment.

Neutral Points:
- The plot is predictable but there's a nice twist that occurs.
- The writing, for the most part, is well-written but there are multiple instances that feel unnatural and far-fetched.
- The voice acting is passable. Bits of awkward writing hamper the actor's speech.

reviewText:
Some free games you should avoid, others you should try out.
You should probably try this one out.
It's a 3D point and click game that has an intrestingly progressinging story. There's quite a bit of dialogue given for each clickable object. You can click on an object multiple times and get more story out of it.
Has no save feature, takes about an hour to beat.
Hold the spacebar to view clickable objects.
Voice acting wasn't great, wasn't terrible either.

That sums it up, have fun!

reviewText: No, this isn't survival horror; it's a short point & click mystery with an emphasis on creepiness that's very much worth playing. I especially enjoyed the nods to Lovecraft and Zork. It's hard to believe it's a tech demo for the upcoming Asylum and The Strange Case of Charles Dexter Ward from Senscape, but it definitely did it's job. Enjoy this nightmarish ride free of charge! Serena awaits...
